name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in Turkey, in particular the removal of elected mayors (2019/2821(RSP)). Before I start this debate, I would like to inform you that, during this week's plenary session, a new system allowing Members to register electronically for the catch-the-eye procedure and for the blue card questioning procedure is being tested. You have already received by e-mail information about the use of this system and there are also written instructions on your benches. You can submit your request to intervene in the debate by using the special keys on the electronic voting machine. Please also note that, in addition to using the electronic system, it will also be possible to submit your request in the usual practice (i.e. by raising a white sheet of paper or by making the request in person at the beginning of the debate to plenary colleagues on the catch-the-eye procedure; and by raising a blue card for the 'blue card question' procedure). This electronic system will be tested during various discussions. For this reason, I would like to remind you to always have the voting card with you so that you can use the system. This system will also be tested during the debate which starts immediately now and, as I said, is the situation in Turkey and in particular the removal of elected mayors.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. If I may give you some advice, go one block further to the Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights and listen to the hearings there! I did that yesterday. This is not about resolutions, it is about people and about their freedom. Yesterday I was able to look into the eyes of Mrs Demirtaé, the woman who is fighting for her husband's freedom. Today we are not talking about Demirta', we are talking about four mayors from Turkey who have been deposed even though they have been democratically elected. Today we are talking about Adnan Seluk Mzraklé, Ahmet Türk, Bedia Özgökae. Today, however, we are talking about more than 400 other people without office and dignity who have been arrested in the same way in this wave of arrests. Today we are also talking about Canan Kaftanc'o'lu, the CHP chairman in Istanbul, who was in istanbul because of a tweet from 2012 – 2012! – has been convicted. And yes, today this resolution is also about the safety of human rights defenders, of people who stand up for other people and risk their freedom and security. For example, Veysel Ok, who was just yesterday convicted for insulting the judiciary, as a lawyer, was not allowed to insult the judiciary. However, this resolution is also about much more: relations between the EU and Turkey. How do we imagine the future of this relationship? This future is difficult, but in this future, 20% of all inmates in Turkish prisons cannot be held there on terror charges without these allegations being properly substantiated. However, this future must remain European. And that is why it is worth arguing with the Turkish Government, because turkish society is colourful, freedom-loving. It is worth fighting for their human rights. I know that not everyone agrees, but I believe that it is important to continue to defend the European perspective with Turkey. However, this perspective is built on a clear common basis, and this basis is respect for each other, but also absolute respect for human rights and the rule of law. That is what this resolution is about.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: Author. – Mr President, I would like to express my satisfaction at the fact that it has been easy to reach agreement on this motion for a resolution with the other groups, and I think it has been easy to reach agreement because the degree of deterioration of human rights is becoming increasingly difficult to find alibis or justifications for what is happening in Turkey. It is obvious, already to everyone, that the Turkish penal system is a device used and sometimes designed to silence political criticism. At the moment, the groups are concerned about what has happened to the government/administrative dismissal of several mayors and their replacement by the same Government, by unelected representatives appointed by the Executive. I would like to stress that these are not limitations on rights following a judicial process. No, it is the mere removal of a mayor, newly elected by his fellow citizens, by the Government, that is, by a competing party, and the appointment for that post of a representative of that same party. There is therefore no process, no judge, no guarantees. Moreover, this procedure is used to threaten other mayors, as has been the case with istanbul's social democratic mayor, who has had to win the election twice in order for power to understand that his popular support was much greater. But I would also like to point out that, in the case of these mayors of the HDP, this is not a matter of part-party solidarity, what we are doing is a defence of local democracy in Turkey, whatever the acronyms of the mayors who are affected by these situations. Look, ladies and gentlemen, there's a lot going on in Turkey. The insecurity of power to maintain control of society is increasingly obvious. I believe that the European Union needs to review its working mechanisms in Turkey, because more and more spaces of hope are opening up in the country.

name: Abir AL-SAHLANI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating mr I would like to begin by thanking all the groups and their representatives for a great cooperation and good negotiations where we kept this resolution very focused on what is important and what is going on right now. This resolution is not just about the fact that the chp's local president in Istanbul, who won the elections in the city of Istanbul, has been given nine years and eight months in prison for posting on social media. Posts that in other countries had not received any legal penalties. It is also about the deposed mayors of the cities of Diyarbakir, Mardin and Van. This resolution also points to a concern we have from the European Parliament about the deeper, broader problem of the challenges of democracy, of human rights persecution, of persecution of opposition politicians, of abuse sabuses of power, of abuse of the use of anti-terror legislation. Turkey is an important country for the EU. But it will also be a key challenge in the EU's foreign policy. I hope that we will not have to have a long list of resolutions of this kind on Turkey. However, I am prepared and the Renew Group is prepared to put Turkey on the agenda again and again when it violates human rights, when it violates the rule of law and democratic principles. I hope that here in the European Parliament today we will vote 'yes' to this resolution and I hope that we will support the democratic development of Turkey and the democratic forces.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There was indeed a local election in Turkey. The people voted, they decided. And what happened afterwards? The elected mayors were unable to carry out their duties, and the municipalities were placed under compulsory administration. Let me be very clear: this is undemocratic, it is unacceptable, and that is exactly what we must say. But not only that; the AKP government is also increasingly attacking CHP politicians. Ms. Canan Kaftanc'o'lu has already been named, the chairwoman of the CHP Istanbul, who was sentenced to almost ten years in prison for any tweets – I repeat. What a madness! At present, in Turkey, for example, more than 5,000 HDP members are behind bars: arrested journalists, opposition activists, critics. They are not doing well. One of the most well-known of these politicians is Selahattin Demirtas; Of course, that includes my solidarity. All of this is happening, and mr Erdogan is not acting out of the situation of strength at the moment, but rather out of weakness, because in the local elections we have seen quite clearly that he had a defeat, the opposition has joined forces and something can change in Turkey. But it is not only the rule of law and the issue of freedom of expression and the press in Turkey that are under threat. There is so much more. Did you know, for example, that Turkey is one of the countries with the highest number of murders of women? Did you know that Turkey has increasing numbers of rapes of children in religious institutions, that workers in Turkey die every day in industrial accidents? Did you know that there is massive repression against trade unionists, that company organisations are being prevented? All of this is vehement for us, and we need to pay more attention to it. Turkey is going through a crisis, an economic and political crisis, and these crises are mutually beneficial. All I can say, therefore, is that the population is worse off. It is all about maintaining power, mr Erdogan. Therefore, let us pay even more attention to Turkey in the coming months, and let us start with our policy. If we change our policy, let us abandon hypocrisy, let us terminate, for example, the refugee pact, because more and more people have to flee here from Turkey because they no longer have a livelihood!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Author. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the co-drafters of this resolution for their cooperation, from which it has been made clear that we are interested in supporting the democratic forces in Turkey and about human and political rights. The government's current position goes beyond the Kurds. In the long term, the situation of the Kurds in Turkey is complicated, but what is happening there really requires our acute action, our appeal to the Turkish Government that it cannot act in this way as a member of the Council of Europe, as a member of NATO. Yes, the PKK is an organisation that even the European Union considers terrorist, but that does not mean that Turkey can apply collective guilt to all Kurdish politicians. This is simply an approach that could ultimately lead to further genocide. The Turkish government is against itself. It should try to find a way out for peaceful relations with the Kurds. And it should not violate its own laws as stated in our resolution. We list the specific names of the mayors who have been removed, replaced by mayors who are from the ruling party. But this is not just the Kurds and the HDP side. The Turkish Government is also pressuring opposition Republicans, which is why we are saying clearly that we will not accept this fact, and Erdogan must count on the fact that the opposition can win in a democratic society, that is simply normal. The opposition has rights and should have the right to exercise its mandate. And let me make one more comment. Not only the European Court of Human Rights, but there is also a new turkish embassy building at the Council of Europe and its consulate, which they certainly plan to use, but if they do not respect human rights, commitments to the Council of Europe, then this beautiful building is being built unnecessarily. They should consider it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I believe that violence, violation of human rights, terrorism inside and outside Turkey has become the norm in recent years. And I am one of those who believe that the issue of breaking the laws and rules for elected mayors is simply a continuation of many other violations that have turned Turkey into an open country of prison, violence and terrorism; a terrorism that is not only confined to Turkey but is also exported to neighbouring countries. Mr President, my whole country is suffering from violence and terrorism, human rights violations, the harsh face of the expansionist policy of occupying Turkey for forty-five years in Cyprus. And that is why today, if we really want to contribute not only with another resolution but with real work as the European Parliament and as democratically elected Members, we must thunder and send with concrete measures the message: 'Zero tolerance in Turkey!'. The European Parliament and the European Union have taken concrete measures for other countries both within the European Union and outside the European Union, without being able to do so, applying principles and values. We are not going to apply discounts and concessions to Turkey. And if we really want to do it, we all owe it – because I imagine that none of you tolerates what my country is suffering or tolerates these human rights violations – we must, I repeat, proceed to freeze Turkey's accession funds. No euros in this country that terrorizes inside and outside Turkey! No support, no help, no substantial support to all those who are really causing trouble and instability within and within Turkey! I firmly believe that this resolution will not move Mr Erdogan either. Mr Erdogan is heavily and significantly dependent on the European Union, and no matter how much he blackmails Cyprus by violating the Exclusive Economic Zone, by violating resolutions on Famagusta and by blackmailing on immigration, you should know, Mr President, that Turkey is very much dependent on the European Union and the freezing of funds. , as well as the freezing of economic and trade relations, is what will really force Turkey to "re-impact the stern" and respect human rights.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the escalation of attacks by the Turkish authorities on press freedom, human rights activists and political opponents has been the subject of continued and growing apprehension over the years.  The recent acts of persecution against local elected officials, in a clear attempt to reverse the results of the elections of March 31, resulting in the arrest and replacement of mayors who, in suffrage, have achieved absolute majorities, by unelected administrators and intimidation directed at other local elected representatives can not fail to be the target of our most alive repudiation.  Failure to vote for citizens is a red line whose overtaking can never be tolerated. The condemnation of Kaftancıoğlu - which is understood as a clear reaction to the CHP's victory in Istanbul - cannot but be the target of our indignation. Anti-terrorism legislation and criminal law cannot be used to silence and remove critics from the established power. The European Union cannot tolerate the attempt to crush the popular will for change and the constant violations of the rule of law in Turkey.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, after 17 years in power, the foundation of Erdogan's regime is beginning to wobble. The June elections were a very clear sign of this: it lost control in seven of Turkey's ten major municipalities. Sentencing some opposition leaders to ten years in prison for terrorism and insulting the president is revenge. It is nothing but revenge, such as harassment and convictions against those who freely express their opinion on social media or against journalists. Erdogan despises democracy, human rights and the political choices of his citizens. The most vivid and recent evidence is the removal of the elected mayors of Diyarbakır, Mardin and Van. Make funding and economic partnerships conditional on respect for human rights, not just for Erdogan, but for all undemocratic regimes that crush freedom.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The European Union as an institution and we parliamentarians as elected representatives, we have to say as it is. What is going on and has been going on for years, months and many, many long times in Turkey is a violation of human rights and international agreements. Hundreds of democratically elected mayors and politicians, students, academics and political activists who have used their democratic right to raise their voice, have been imprisoned and accused of terrorism and of being enemies of Turkey. We Greens, we call on the Turkish authorities to release the arrested and drop the charges against them immediately and without conditions. And we remind Erdoğan that we see you. We see what you do and we will continue to resist because history has taught us that we have no other choice.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In Turkey, the situation is once again getting worse. Erdogan is once again acting as an absolute ruler and is now threatening the EU with a new migrant rush – that is blackmail 2.0. He is cracking down on the opposition, waging a war against the Kurds at home, and that now culminates in his claim to power with the removal of democratically elected mayors. The official reason is usually the support of the PKK. The strong criticism of the opposition, former Prime Minister Davutoglu and former President Gül clearly shows the predicatory nature of these official justifications. The EU must now not only condemn this undemocratic behaviour and its threats like a mule, as usual, but must finally draw the necessary conclusions. I therefore urge the European Commission to finally end the accession negotiations with Turkey – once and for all! Turkey is not part of Europe.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: for the ECR group. – Mr President, I have been a member of the EU-Turkey Association Committee for 15 years since 2004, but this is not the first time I have joined this committee, simply because it seems to me that the talks on Turkey's EU membership have reached an impasse. And I say this as someone who has traditionally supported Turkey, but I have had to change my mind. One of the points at which this turnaround occurred was the situation after the suppression of the failed coup, when there were large purging in the military, in the judiciary, in the state administration, in the academic sphere and in the media. And these repressions have really reached an unprecedented level, and now we are experiencing something similar in the attack of the government regime or the governing party on democratically elected politicians, and I think we have to say that this is really unacceptable. And I have a feeling that it would be appropriate to be fair, to stop playing with Turkey and to say that under these conditions, in this situation, we simply cannot consider Turkey's membership of the European Union and say it to the fullest.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! Dear colleagues! The situation in Turkey is totally unacceptable. Democratically elected Kurdish mayors are forcibly removed, the leftist pro-Kurdish presidential candidate and former party chairman, Selahattin Demirtaş, are in prison. His only crime is to have used his freedom of speech. Thousands of mayors, parliamentarians and members of the HDP party are also imprisoned. Ladies and gentlemen, repression in Turkey must have consequences. Erdogan's breach of fundamental democratic rights must not be accepted, action must be taken. Ladies and gentlemen, the EU's billion-dollar aid to Turkey should be stopped until fundamental democratic rights are guaranteed, the people of Turkey deserve it, it deserves the democratic opposition in Turkey, and european taxpayers deserve that.

name: Annunziata Mary REES-MOGG
text: – Mr President, thank you to the 452 321 East Midlands voters who put their faith in the Brexit Party. Today’s so-called debate regards the state of democracy in the Kurdish areas in the south and east of Turkey. Understandably, it is of concern to us all to see democracy called into question in our neighbour. It is surely bizarre then that the EU has still not ruled out Turkish accession to its supposedly democratic Union. Of course, the real hypocrisy is calling for free and fair democracy in non-EU countries such as Turkey, whilst trying to undermine voters’ wishes in their own Member States.  Just yesterday, British MEPs from less successful parties were calling for a further delay to Brexit ‘to sort it out’. They mean to undo the will of the British people. It is sad when members of this aspirational federation preach one thing to Turkey, and simultaneously betray their own members’ democratic mandate.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, we all know that Turkey is an extremely important neighbour to the European Union. In addition to the issue of economic exchange, the issue of migration, which we have already heard a lot about, is also extremely important the influence of Turkey on the territory of Southeast Europe, especially Bosnia and Herzegovina. Turkey has been pro-government in Bosnia and Herzegovina for years, primarily through Bosniak parties, and this is something that definitely cannot and must not be ignored in any way. Unfortunately, bosnia and herzegovina's European path is largely threatened by certain political parties there, it is threatened by those who do not respect the decisions of the Constitutional Court and who actually deny and impede the rule of law by the end of equality of one of the constituent peoples, which is Croatian. Unfortunately, such a situation also has to do with this projection of interest and power that I was talking about. As far as Turkey itself is concerned, unfortunately in recent years we have found a situation there where there is a twilight of democracy, where we actually have the advancement and degradation of fundamental human rights, democracy and the rule of law and constitutional order, and this has intensified in particular following the unsuccessful coup in 2016. We've had a situation of purges of unseaid personnel in the education system, in the media, in the judiciary, and the highlight of that is what we're talking about today, which is the dismissal of legally elected local leaders and replacing those installed from the top. Unfortunately, this degradation is not good, this degradation shows that Turkey deviates from all those principles established by the founder of the modern Turkish republic Kemal Atatürk, which are democracy, the rule of law and a modern secular state that as such has also submitted a candidacy for the European Union. In order for Turkey to remain on good terms with the European Union, so that these neighbourly relations can develop, it is essential that Turkey returns to those standards established before, that such situations of dismissal of elected officials are prevented, that Turkey returns to democracy, the rule of law and that the demographic treatment of the ruling party and its president is impeded.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, Turkey is indeed an extremely important neighbour to us, it is politically, economically and also in terms of public interaction. I visited Turkey a week ago and met people who were optimistic, believer in the future at the same time, they saw the possibility of political change through democracy and elections and, on the other hand, they were concerned about what they see as precisely the central government's measure towards democratically elected local decision-makers, mayors. Turkey has applied to join the EU. It is a member of the Council of Europe. It is committed to democratic principles in its own administration and to the results of the elections. So we cannot remain silent about what has happened in Turkey. We cannot accept the ousting of legally elected mayors. The Turks are looking at us. By adopting Parliament's strong position, we are sending a clear message both to the Turkish regime and to the Turkish people: we are also there for democracy in Turkey.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will ask two questions. Why does the level of repression never recede in Turkey? Why is Mr Erdogan now in the making of elected mayors whose only wrong is being Kurdish? This relentlessness, this frenzy, seems at first glance incomprehensible, except that hope is reborn in Turkey, as two of our colleagues have just recalled.  Ankara has switched to opposition, Istanbul has amplified its first vote in favour of a young and brilliant Kemalist, social discontent is growing even in the AKP electorate and, last disavowal for this president, three of the greatest figures of his own party have just slammed the door to found new formations. Mr Erdogan is worried, he has reasons to be, that is why he is hitting more and more blindly, and that is why our Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, has so much to defend the democrats of this country over and over again.

name: François ALFONSI
text: Mr President, the emergency resolution on the situation in Turkey that we are debating is motivated by the new and serious attacks on democracy committed by Mr Erdogan's regime. The arbitrary removal of the municipal authorities from the three major cities of Kurdistan, for the sole reason of the political orientation of those chosen by the voters, is deeply shocking. Of course, you have to react forcefully. Our resolution will strengthen the hope of those in Turkey who are fighting for democracy. But our Parliament must also be aware that these facts have a well-defined political framework, that of the struggle of the Kurdish people for the recognition of their historical rights. Turkey's shift towards ever more worrying anti-democratic excesses is linked to the refusal of dialogue within the Turkish state on the institutional future of Kurdistan, which aspires to genuine political autonomy. This dialogue is essential if we are to build a sustainable democracy in Turkey tomorrow. Europe can and must contribute to its establishment.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the umpteenth purge of the Turkish Prime Minister, Mr Erdoğan, must not be ignored, this time involving the mayors of the three most important Kurdish cities, democratically elected and with large majorities. These mayors, who are sum-heartedly accused of being linked to armed PKK separatist groups, have been removed and replaced by governors welcomed by the central government. I too have been mayor and I am well aware of the bond of trust that there is with the citizens. I am therefore indignant because, once again, Erdoğan thinks that he can trample on the will of the people with impunity. The European Union, through the President of the Commission and the High Representative for Foreign Policy, must respond in concrete actions to a leader who never fails to threaten the West, repress the fundamental freedoms of the people and fuel the worst Islamic radicalism. The procedure for Turkey's accession to the European Union, given also the total lack of progress in the negotiations and the ever-open question of Northern Cyprus, must not only be abolished but, in my humble opinion and if we want to be consistent with the principles of democracy and freedom on which this Europe of ours is based, must be declared concluded and rejected.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every time we talk about Turkey, a picture comes to my mind: on the one hand, Mr Erdogan is holding the four million refugees in one hand and in the other hand his country's trade balance sheets with European countries and blowing them menacingly towards European leaders. And they stay bent and on their knees. As long as this image does not change, Turkey will slip into authoritarianism. It will continue to hold Cyprus hostage, to circumvent democracy, to restrict freedoms, to set aside and to expel mayors and even prime ministers, to persecute both Turks and Kurds, whether they are politicians, journalists or intellectuals. Mrs von der Leyen and other European officials, change this picture, if you will and if you can, so that we can finally get on with all this embarrassment.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Mr President, I hear about democratic sensitivities and things like that in this Chamber. Of course you are absolutely right to talk about what is happening in Turkey. But I would like to talk to you as a man who has experienced these things. You know, I've been elected as an MP four times in the last few years in the Greek Parliament. But six years ago there was an illegal and unjust prosecution against us - me, the head of the party I then myself was and five other MPs. We went to prison for eighteen months and stayed there illegally after interventions by the country's then Prime Minister Antonis Samaras and with pressure exerted on prosecutors, according to audiovisual material, which exists and which is at your disposal and at the disposal of anyone who has doubts about all this. So these are flagrant violations of human rights and elected Members. As far as Turkey is concerned, its attitude, of course, is unacceptable. Turkey must be punished. Turkey has never been and will never be a member of the European Union. And the problem is not Erdogan in Turkey. It's Turkey itself. So she has learned to act and trample on all international conventions and all laws by doing only what she wants.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Mr President, replacing the three democratically elected mayors does not violate the will of the citizens of Turkey's three cities. It violates democracy itself. Turkey, especially after the 2016 coup, is moving towards a peculiar authoritarianism that is inconsistent with the principles and values of the European Union. Turkey does not respect the principles of the rule of law and democracy. He doesn't respect good neighbourly relations. It does not respect the sovereign rights of its neighbours, such as, for example, the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus and Greece, which have been grossly violated all this time. The European Union must take concrete action. Europe wants a democratic Turkey in Europe. But he does not want the behaviour of a country that threatens Europe, that does not respect Europe. With today's resolution we condemn another undemocratic attitude and action by the Turkish leadership and Mr Erdogan personally.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Yesterday I was an audience member at the trial of Selahattin Demirtaş, the former Kurdish HDP co-chairman, against the Turkish state at the European Court of Human Rights. It was clear from the Commissioner for Human Rights that there are serious shortcomings in the Turkish legal system, to say the least. According to the Committee to Protect Journalists' 2018 compilation, Turkey has the most imprisoned journalists worldwide. In addition, a few weeks ago, the three HDP mayors of the Kurdish cities of Diyarbakir, Mardin and Van were forcibly deposed, less than five months after the local elections in Turkey. And during this particular session, I received a text message saying that yesterday even more mayors were forcibly deposed in Diyarbakir province. Like many others, they are accused of terrorism, even though they have worked peacefully for democracy and the freedom of all peoples in the country. It is important that we in the European Parliament, which is an important voice in the fight for a democratic and equal world, raise our voices and demand the release of all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU will continue to transfer EUR 1.18 billion in accession aid to Turkey by next year, instead of finally breaking off these talks. This is also – and especially – against the background of the so-called refugee agreement with Erdogan, which was born out of incompetence and unwillingness to secure its own borders. Whether and if so, to what extent this Turkey agreement has actually contributed to the reduction in migratory flows, is still questionable, despite a total of EUR 6 billion in European payments. And now Turkey is once again threatening to withdraw from this agreement. We see what has happened to the mayors in Turkey. Some here seem to enjoy being constantly blackmailed. The European Union can be guided through the manege at the nose ring. The majority of citizens do not share these masochistic tendencies. It wants clarity and not Turkey's accession to the EU. I also call on you to stop the accession talks immediately, stop the payments and finally create clear conditions for dealing with a despot!

name: James WELLS
text: – Mr President, while we debate this worrying situation I would like to highlight EU hypocrisy on the question of democracy. Municipal elections took place across Turkey earlier this year, which led to the opposition party winning in Istanbul. However, at an AKP party meeting Mr Erdogan said re-running the vote was the best step for Turkey to solve its problems within a framework of democracy and law. Most of us were outraged on this, rightly so. In fact, our very own Guy Verhofstadt said: ‘this is an outrageous decision that highlights Turkey is drifting towards dictatorship, and that under such leadership accession talks are impossible.’ So whilst, on the one hand, the EU’s lead Brexit coordinator says a country cannot join the EU for overturning an election, on the other hand, he gives his support to the Lib Dems via attending their party conference to overturn a democratic election in the UK.

name: Sara SKYTTEDAL
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In theory, there are many reasons to show patience towards Turkey. It is a formal candidate country that has also remedied and played a major role in the migration crisis that has challenged our Member States. But in the end you get to a situation where patience is running out. Many of us have hoped for positive developments in Turkey and for the democratic institutions to be stabilised. Since the attempted coup in 2016, the situation has become increasingly untenable. Erdoğan and the AKP show no signs that change is waiting in another direction. We live in a time where there is a risk that we don't attach any importance to when we get seemingly repetitive news updates about the same country. My concern is that notices of the erosion of the rule of law, the dismantling of democratic institutions and the imprisonment of dissidents do not even get our attention, at a time when we are constantly being overwhelmed by messages and likes. The desandly of the mayor elected on 31 March this year is just the latest example of Erdoğan pushing the boundaries and testing our patience. An example that should not go unnoticed. Because Turkey is not just any country; Turkey is a candidate country to become a member of the European Union and there must be a limit to how far away from democratic principles one can move and is still considered to be on the road to full EU membership.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdoğan has unfortunately accustomed us to very serious actions, such as the removal of newly democratically elected mayors, where the result was not congenial to him, all the more so if he were Kurds or close to the Kurds, in the South-East region in particular, demonstrating once again that the vote for him is nothing more than a simulacrum of a democracy that is partly no longer there. What can be called democracy when an opposition leader, Selahattin Demirtaş, has been in prison for almost three years for political reasons and is not allowed by Members like myself and other colleagues to visit him, as we tried to do with a mission in 2016? For these and many other reasons, in our work on the European Union's financial instruments in recent years, we have given very strong signals to Ankara, taking european funds away precisely in areas affected by the authoritarian removal of mayors, drastically cutting the resources allocated to the country as a candidate for accession, and drawing up the remaining funds for civil society, which is fighting every day for fundamental rights and freedoms. Erdoğan make a reason for it: we will never stop countering his authoritarianism, we will support turkish society that is still alive and demanding strong change. We're not going to turn our backs on her.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as history teaches us, Turkey has never been, is not and will never be Europe. Today, Turkey is a country of 80 million Muslims, where democracy, freedom and human rights are daily violated by Erdoğan's Islamist dictatorship. In recent years, Europe has given Billions of Euros to Turkey, favouring a country that is against European democracy, against our values and against our freedom. I would remind you that the dictator Erdoğan has repeatedly threatened to bring wars of religion into our countries and into our cities. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to put an end to this false buonismo. We must have the courage to say this loud and clear: the European Union must immediately and forever stop negotiations on Turkey's accession to Europe.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, I have heard too many findings today, too many conclusions. I think it's time for measures. It is the only language Turkey understands. That's clear. I'm almost the same age as the Turks invaded my country. And I am telling you very frankly, as a Cypriot MEP, that I am tired, I have had enough of verbal support, of resolutions, which Turkey is throwing in the bin. Are we ready as the European Union to take decisive action because it is the only language Erdogan understands? Let's do it! I think it's time we did. My country is also a victim of this policy that we are discussing today. The Turkish drilling rigs as we speak, ignoring the law and the laws, with the support of the Navy have surrounded my country. At the same time, they are moving towards the colonization of Famagusta, ignoring every United Nations resolution. Ladies and gentlemen, this pirated behaviour must not be accepted by anyone. I ask that you join forces with us to take measures to bring costs to the Erdogan regime. A clear message must finally be sent to Ankara that any illegal action will come at a cost and what we need is cooperation and peace and not Turkish "bullies". I call on you to stand by us, taking effective and effective measures to tackle Turkish piracy at home and abroad.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, the removal of the three Kurdish mayors raises an essential question that we must all answer: does today's Turkey have a democratic state? Regardless of views, the answer was given yesterday before the European Court of Human Rights. It was given with a legally substantiated opinion by the Council of Europe's Commissioner for Human Rights, who found that there is a systematic failure in Turkey for an independent and impartial administration of justice. So the question for us is this: can justice be used in a country as a tool by the government and at the same time that this country is a democracy? So the Erdogan regime, which uses the judiciary as a tool, is the same one that is intervening in Bulgaria, Bosnia, but unfortunately also in my country, in the northern occupied part of Cyprus, which has even recently been trying to islamise in a brutal way. So the question for us, Mr President, is: are we going to issue another resolution or are we going to take measures that come at a cost?

name: Philippe OLIVIER
text: Mr President, recently the Turkish President, Mr Erdogan, threatened to let a wave of migration pour into Europe if he did not receive additional funds. We are paying for the guilty mistake of giving others our vital protection. Mr. Erdogan, who sees himself as a sultan of the new Ottoman Empire, knows that politics is a balance of power. It is customary for these unfriendly behaviours. He is attacking Greece or Cyprus, and when one of our colleagues points it out in this Chamber, the House does not hear it. It is instrumentalizing Turkish diasporas in our countries and the European Union is turning its head. The situation we are living with Turkey speaks for itself: the EU has made Europe the empire of weakness. But above all, by destroying our border protections, the EU has disarmed our nations and placed them under the threat of a migratory submersion now used as a weapon of mass destruction. It's not just a mistake, it's a forfeiture.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, we are in the same spectators' work: Turkey brutally provoking and insulting all notions of respect for human rights and European values, and we as Europe are committed to theoretical declarations and resolutions, without Turkey complying with our calls. What are the results of these policies? Replace democratically elected mayors with the usual charge of harboring terrorism and replace them with state institutions by administrative decisions. Continue for three years the illegal detention of HDP leader Sellachatin Demirtas. Imprison journalists and criminalize any unlikable political activity. To invade the EEZ of a Member State of the European Union and threaten to colonize the city of Famagusta.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is absolutely clear to everyone, and this has emerged in this debate, the enormous authoritarian involution that Turkey has been experiencing in recent years. The removal of the three mayors, all hdp, diyarbakır, mardin and van, is unfortunately only the most recent episode in the battle being fought by the Turkish Government against the main sources of internal dissent: academics, lawyers, human rights defenders, political opponents, elected Members of Parliament and local institutions, including many citizens of the Islamic faith. All uncomfortable and contrasting voices. So what remains of a large and important country is currently experiencing an extremely worrying democratic and civil crisis, also considering the geopolitical role that Turkey plays at international level. A crisis that Europe and its diplomacy cannot ignore. The question also arises, within this framework, whether it is possible to continue with the outsourced management of a part of our borders, entrusting Turkey with the management, in practice, of part of the refugee affair without any guarantee of humanity or respect for human rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Author. – Mr President, bravo, colleagues! After decades of human rights abuses, the arrest of journalists, their imprisonment after interfering in the internal affairs of many countries, including Bulgaria, after it was clear to everyone that Mr. Erdogan was pure and just a dictator, you finally found in this chamber that he was violating human rights. As they say, a remarkable political flair! Congratulations! As the wise Bulgarian people said" Better late than never. Yes, Erdogan is a dictator. Yes, it violates electoral rights. Yes, he's putting journalists in jail. We all know this thing, and you keep giving it money. Billions poured into Turkey so he could continue to do these things – billions of European money, european taxpayers' money. It's a strange hypocrisy, incomprehensible to me. I'm giving you one more example. Currently, a large German company, Volkswagen, negotiates with Turkey to export its plant there – in violation of human rights, illegal state aid, in that Turkey pollutes the air and does not comply with any environmental norms. Again, a European conglomerate will pour billions there. This is unacceptable, wrong. It's hypocrisy and double standards.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, join my colleagues in condemning this action, which is the removal of democratically elected mayors in Turkey. I think we are witnessing a wider phenomenon of violations of fundamental human rights in Turkey. And it must be said that Turkey is committed to respecting these rights, it is a party to the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Freedoms within the Council of Europe. Instead of respecting these fundamental human rights, we see false accusations, we are witnessing condemnation and, of course, violations of the most fundamental rights, not only those I have referred to here, be it freedom of expression, the right to a legal court, but, of course, violations of the rights to self-government. Turkey has also signed the Charter of Local Government, which is part of the Council of Europe. Within the Council of Europe, the instruments for pressing states within the Council of Europe on Turkey are limited. But we have the tools, and let's try to use them.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the removal of three recently elected HDP mayors by the Turkish authorities follows a previous two-and-a-half-year-long government appointed trustee rule in Kurdish municipalities, which not only severely circumvented local democracy, but also devastated municipal infrastructures with embezzlement, cronyism and bribery. Since their election in May, the HDP mayors had worked to bring their municipalities back to a functional state by paying debts and restoring essential services, including the payment of workers’ salaries. I am proud to be a friend of HDP. I have visited Diyarbakir many times and I was shocked to see the militarisation of the city under AKP administration, the town hall surrounded by razor wire and barricades, and armoured vehicles and soldiers everywhere. I tried to imagine if this was my city and I was simply trying to pay my council tax; we would be outraged. These communities need our solidarity, which is why I’m encouraging Labour mayors to join a twinning project with Kurdish mayors. As the removed mayors say, ‘We feel empowered when we hear voices of solidarity from across borders’.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: – Mr President, the mayors of Diyarbakir, Van and Mardin have been intervened by the Government of Erdogan. To shore up his regime, mayors, left-wing activists, feminists, critical teachers and any form of dissent are dismissed and imprisoned. And all this happens with the complicit silence of the European Union. For border management alone we have delivered more than two billion euros to Erdogan. The figure is higher if we include the neighbourhood funds and the own funds it receives as a candidate to join the European Union. And this aid has a clear addition: that the European Union looks the other way when the AKP government attacks the rights of the majority. It is imperative that all European Union cooperation with Turkey, including union access negotiations, freezes until Turkey meets the most basic human rights standards, starting with the release of all political prisoners. As long as the European Union continues to put its economic interests or xenophobic migration policies above the rights of the Turkish and Kurdish peoples, neither this Parliament nor any Community institution will be able to give human rights lessons to Erdogan.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this timely debate, which unfortunately proves that the concerns previously discussed in this plenary on the rule of law situation in Turkey are still relevant.  Turkey’s local elections in March and June witnessed a voter turnout that the people of Turkey can rightly be proud of. However, ensuring that democracy goes well beyond the balloting process on voting day requires a political environment with freedom of expression and respect for plurality. It is central that elected representatives are able to exercise their political mandate freely and without fear of repression, dismissal or detention.  Following the March elections, we saw the decision to declare elected mayors ineligible to assume office and to give mayoral mandates to the candidates with the second highest number of votes. As High Representative Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn expressed, this undermines the electoral process and goes against the core aim of ensuring that the will of the people prevails. The respect for democratic outcomes was further put into question with the suspension last month of the mayors of the cities of Mardin, Van and Diyarbakir, who were replaced by state governors. This deprives voters of political representation at local level and seriously damages democracy.  Turkey must repeal measures that inhibit local democracy. This follows clearly from the recommendations of the Venice Commission and from Turkey’s obligations as a member of the Council of Europe. As we have said to the Turkish authorities multiple times, we are conscious of Turkey’s security challenges and its right to fight terrorism. However, those security challenges cannot justify dismissals for political reasons, applying broad anti-terror or criminal legislation. Unfortunately, the negative developments in the rule of law are not limited to the recent local elections. There are still a large number of journalists, writers, academics, politicians and human rights defenders in detention in Turkey, for instance, Osman Kavala, who has been detained for almost two years, or Selahattin Demirtaş whose case was heard yesterday by the Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights. We’ve also seen a dramatic increase in prosecutions for insulting the President, as exemplified by the case of Canan Kaftancioğlu. The European Union has consistently called upon Turkey to ensure the respect of fundamental freedoms in accordance with Turkey’s obligations as a candidate country and as a member of the Council of Europe. This is not just about Turkey’s status as a candidate country. It is also about the kind of country Turkish citizens want and deserve, a country with stronger institutions, a more inclusive country and a country where they can all find their place and contribute to Turkish society’s collective progress. In the European Union we will continue to work to support a strong, free, safe, prosperous and democratic Turkey as a key neighbour and partner in our region, not just as a candidate country. It is in our shared interest to contribute to this and all Turkish citizens should know that they can count on the European Union.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the end of the discussions. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. – The Turkish Interior Ministry’s removal of three democratically elected mayors in the major municipalities of the Kurdish regions due to terrorism-related charges is worrying. All three mayors were active members in People’s Democratic Party (HDP), an opposition party to the ruling government. The motive of the violation of the rights of these mayors remains unclear. Nonetheless, it fits well into the pattern of persecution and consolidation of power against the Kurdish population and opposition to the standing government. The Turkish authorities made a regrettable decision, which stands as a demonstration of ignorance of free and fair expression of the will of the Turkish people. The countries around the world and the EU, call on the Turkish authorities to reinstate the mayors of Diyarbakır, Van and Mardin, if the charges against them are proven unfounded. The mayors must be afforded fair a due legal process.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. The situation in Turkey is a cause for concern; Turkey has left the path of democracy. The arbitrary action against democratically elected mayors is not compatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, but rather represents a clear violation of the European Convention on Human Rights. Turkey must also comply with the rulings of the European Court of Human Rights. What is shocking is that the opposition leader and presidential candidate Selahattin Demirtas is still in custody – a judicial scandal that the European Parliament has today strongly criticised with the resolution.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Myanmar/Burma, in particular the situation of the Rohingya (2019/2822(RSP))

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I am speaking as a co-author of this important resolution, a resolution that is beyond division. I recently met bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina Wajed a few months ago. We have talked about the fact that it is a poor, although large (larger than Russia in demographic terms) state has accepted hundreds of thousands of refugees precisely the Rohingya people from Myanmar. This is therefore a problem not only for Myanmar/Burma, but also for neighbouring countries. I think that today our voice on this issue is needed, it is important, it will certainly be heard. This is, moreover, another European Parliament resolution on this issue, but it is not enough to ever talk about human rights and respect for things that are quite fundamental, such as the right to profess one's faith.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Mr President, this is not the first time this House has debated the situation of the Rohingya in Myanmar, has called for a stop to the human tragedy, and urged the world to take action. This is not a crisis that began with the exodus in August 2017: over a million Rohingya refugees have fled violence in Myanmar in successive waves of displacement since the early 1990s. The vast majority of those who have fled and reached Bangladesh are women and children, and more than 40% are under age 12. Many walked for days through the forest to reach safety, including pregnant women, young children, the sick and the elderly. Too many children are growing up in Kutupalong and Nayapara refugee camps in the Cox’s Bazar district. The refugee settlement has become the largest refugee camp in the world, with more than 600 000 people living in an area of just 13 km2. For many children, those are the only places they have ever known, and they are vulnerable to disease and lack sufficient access to education. This is heart—breaking. The world that is watching owes these children a duty of care. We all remember that in 2018 the UN independent fact—finding mission concluded that crimes against humanity and possibly genocide had been committed against the Rohingya. In its further report in 2019 the UN fact—finding mission reported severe ongoing sexual and gender—based violence, including systematic rape, gang rape and forced sexual acts by the Myanmar military and security forces against Rohingya women, children and transgender people. Yet, the authorities in Myanmar refused to investigate seriously human rights violations against Rohingya and to hold the perpetrators accountable. Not only that, Myanmar continues to deny that these rights violations ever occurred in the first place – claims that are contradicted by extensive good-quality evidence and individual witness accounts. The highest-ranking military, who supervised the attacks against the Rohingya population, remain in their posts. Myanmar has so far refused to allow a UN Human Rights Council fact—finding mission to enter the country. Despite the Government of Myanmar having withdrawn cooperation with the UN special rapporteur, the special rapporteur continues to seek to engage and assist with human rights issues. So it is high time for action. The Council has prolonged its restrictive measures in place in Myanmar for one year. These measures include asset freezes and travel bans on 14 senior military and other security officials of Myanmar. The decision of the International Criminal Court to open a preliminary investigation into crimes, under the court’s jurisdiction, committed against the Rohingya population is a welcome step towards accountability. Peace does not come without justice. The perpetrators of these most serious crimes must be held accountable.

name: Neena GILL
text: author. – Mr President, since hundreds and thousands of Rohingya were forced out of their homes through mass atrocities and repeated acts of humiliation and violence in Myanmar, nearly one million people are still living in camps in Cox’s Bazar, struggling for safety, survival and dignity as refugees in Bangladesh. More than 25 000 children are out of school and 97% of those aged 15 to 18 do not attend any type of educational facility. They need our action and our support now more than ever. Sadly their plight has fallen down our list of priorities, and, as one of the instigators of this resolution, I urge the EU: we must find a solution and end this crisis. Bangladesh cannot be left alone to cope with large numbers of refugees. We have to engage in dialogue with our partners in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to ensure the Rohingya people’s rights are upheld, so they can start living their lives normally, where women and girls are safe and children have access to education.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, the latest UN fact-finding mission on Myanmar warned that the approximately 600 000 Rohingya who remain in Myanmar live under the threat of genocide. The crimes against humanity and war crimes against ethnic communities by the Myanmar army continue, and the army and the Government enjoy impunity for their crimes. The Rohingya in Myanmar are being discriminated against and denied their basic rights, and are subjected to arbitrary arrests, lack of freedom of movement and limited health care. The more than 700 000 Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh, who have fled the violence and genocide in Myanmar, are also facing serious problems as the refugee camps are overcrowded, have unsanitary conditions and provide limited access to maternal and health care for women and children. The children lack access to education and there is a rising problem of human and sex trafficking. EU and other international organisations must work towards gaining access to the conflict areas and places of segregation in Myanmar, in order to deliver aid and to monitor the situation on the ground. We must continue stressing the need for Myanmar to give citizenship and full civil rights to the Rohingya. Investigation of the human rights violations must take place and perpetrators must be held accountable. The EU must seriously consider using the tools it has – by way of extending entry bans, targeted sanctions and freezing of assets – to influence the Myanmar Government and military to stop these atrocities, and should finally review the trade preferences that benefit Myanmar.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Mr President, as the author of this resolution too, I would like to stress the importance of the European Parliament speaking out about what has been the violation of the human rights of the Rohingya people, but also sexual violence against women and children.  It is a fundamental issue and, to denounce, it is indeed important. But the European Union has to do more than denounce and, therefore, I call on colleagues to please reconsider again what they have not considered in the negotiations of this joint resolution, which is to take into account the report of the international and independent mission which refers to and urges the international community to end relations with myanmar's military forces , but also with the vast network of companies that these forces control and depend on.  This international mission considers that the revenue staked by these military forces through domestic and foreign trade agreements has significantly strengthened their ability to commit serious human rights violations with impunity.  The European Union has preferential relations at the commercial level. Human rights are not for sale. Please appeal to you. Include this, because more than reporting is taking responsibility.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, let me say one thing. In the area of human rights, the European Union is the engine and engine of the whole world. I do not know of any democratic institution that so often comments on human rights and appeals for an investigation into war crimes, such as war crimes. The European Parliament and other European institutions. And why are we doing this? Because we are not indifferent to the fate of the tens or hundreds of thousands of people who are suffering in Myanmar today. This is not the first resolution, it is a multiple resolution. And I have to say that I very often negotiate similar human rights resolutions on the People's Party of Europe, but rarely do these parties agree on everything as they did in the case of this resolution, which appeals very clearly – we want an investigation into the crimes committed by Myanmar soldiers against the Rohingya. We really want to address the situation of hundreds of thousands of people who are now without any education, who are without any help, who are in appalling conditions somewhere on the islands or in the parts that have been reserved for them by the surrounding states. We want the situation not to get any worse. We want an open dialogue that the Government of Myanmar may not like, but we want to talk to it about tackling this humanitarian crisis and the whole situation, and that is why we are appealing to the European Commission, which has those effective instruments in hand, to really start doing something about the situation of the Rohingya. To be the engine that will take other states in and try to create something that will finally start to address this situation after seven years.

name: David LEGA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, since 2000 more than 700 000 of the Rohingya people have been forced to abandon their homes in Myanmar to become refugees in Bangladesh, and we know that the armed forces continue to cause widespread terror in the Rohingya community through committing appalling human rights violations. These include killings burnings of villages and systematic gender-based violence. We know that the Myanmar authorities enabled these crimes by continuously turning a blind eye and by refusing to hold those responsible accountable. By creating telecommunication blackouts in the northern and central parts of Rakhine state, making media coverage and access impossible, and by refusing to collaborate with UN mechanisms. And we also know that approximately 40% of the Rohingya refugees situated in camps in Bangladesh are children, who are now forced to grow up in overcrowded refugee camps, without hope and without a future. I myself did a field trip to Myanmar together with UNICEF two years ago, and without access to formal education the future of Rohingya children is disappearing right before their eyes. The politicians of Myanmar are not protecting the Rohingya people either. Mr President, we all know the saying, ‘all it takes for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing’. Last century Europe suffered the horrible consequences of the Holocaust, when good men did nothing. In the case of the Rohingyas, the politicians of Myanmar need to do more and we need to do more.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr. President, on Monday, the experts of the UN mission presented a report confirming that 600,000 Rohingya are living under the threat of genocide in Myanmar. A year ago, these same experts reported genocidal acts against the Rohingya. Since August 2017, 740,000 Rohingya have been forced to flee Myanmar for Bangladesh. The Rohingya today are the world's most persecuted minority and the largest stateless group. Highlighting these injustices, we have talked about a lot, is of course important. Highlighting these crimes is important to us, but it is not enough. We therefore call for the Union, but also the international community, to call for those responsible for these crimes to be held accountable. We call for the Eu and the international community to be able to take sanctions, particularly against the 100 officers involved in these crimes and cited in the UN report. We call for a review of the trade relationship with Myanmar in the light of this crime against humanity.

name: Phil BENNION
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the Rohingya are one of the ethnic and religious groups in Myanmar that were not given official status as an ethnic identity, and, as a result, not issued with identity documents. Since 2011, the ethnic conflict with the Rohingya, fuelled by religious and ethnic leaders, has been escalated by the Myanmar military, who are not under the control of the Government. Allegations of crimes against humanity and ethnic cleansing have been raised by the UN Secretary-General, and in 2017 I also brought the issue to the executive of Liberal International through an urgency resolution. The cooperation and support of Bangladesh has been welcomed, but I have felt it necessary this week to complain to the Bangladeshi Ambassador about recent restrictions to rights and freedoms at the camp in Cox’s Bazar. I believe that the Rohingya should have full rights to citizenship in Myanmar. It has been their home and country for generations. They can’t possibly be asked to state that they are foreigners. The return of the Rohingya refugees and internally displaced persons in a safe and dignified manner, as citizens of Myanmar, the reconstruction of their villages and the restitution of their land are all imperative. I want to see the Myanmar Government fulfil its obligations under international law to protect all individuals on its soil, whatever their race or religion.

name: Baroness Nosheena MOBARIK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Rohingya tragedy is becoming another of the many unresolved human rights issues which the UN can add to its list. Bangladesh, clearly struggling with its own challenges, has been left with the fallout of its neighbour’s ghastly actions. The process of proof of identity – cataloguing that of refugees – has resulted in 3 450 people being given approval by the Myanmar authorities to return. At this rate, it would take Bangladesh hundreds of years to get through close to a million displaced people on their doorstep, and those identified would have to be willing to return without a guarantee of their safety and security. The UN must take meaningful measures to restore the basic human rights and freedoms of the Rohingya, whose ancestors have lived in Rakhine State for close to 1 000 years, and those guilty of crimes against humanity must be brought to justice. I call on this House to stand by our principles and support this resolution.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, two years on and time stands still for over a million persecuted Rohingya refugees who are unable to return to a land that is their home, after the violence they have faced. The recently failed attempt to repatriate refugees to Myanmar demonstrates the inadequacy of the return conditions. The Myanmar Government must create conditions that can enable safe, dignified and voluntary returns. According to the International Rescue Committee, there are a million Rohingya refugees surviving purely on humanitarian aid. So I urge the EU and the international community to create a medium—term plan to deal with the impact of this crisis, and to call on Myanmar to address the root causes, including systematic persecution and violence. There must be no military impunity for the grave human rights violations committed against the Rohingya community. There must be sustainable conditions to enable the community to thrive, and not merely to survive, after the suffering they have faced. Finally, I’d like to pay tribute to my Labour colleagues Afzal Khan and Wajid Khan for all their work on this issue.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Undoubtedly, the largest persecuted religious group in the world is Christians. Persecution of Christians already covers 128 countries. The European Parliament has so far dealt – and I hope that in this term of office it will be even more intensive – in defending the rights of Christians, but if we want to be credible in defending the rights of Christians, we must also pay attention to the persecution of other religious groups. Undoubtedly, one of the most persecuted religious and ethnic groups is the Rohingya people. The persecution that began decades ago, unfortunately, continues after a period of democratisation of Myanmar. We all hoped that after 2015, when the National League for Democracy took power in Myanmar, these persecutions would cease. Unfortunately, more than 700,000 people have been pushed out of Myanmar to Bangladesh since 2017, and the 600,000 that remain in Myanmar are still being persecuted.  Myanmar is a potentially very rich country because of its deposits, natural resources. It is also a geostrategically extremely important country, hence the increased activity of world powers such as China, Russia, the United States and the European Union, but Myanmar will not return to its rightful place in the international community unless it solves the problem.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Prosecutor's Office at the International Criminal Court in The Hague last July initiated proceedings to investigate crimes against humanity precisely with regard to the situation of the Rohingya in Myanmar, which is one of the worst humanitarian crises in which, once again, children are the most affected. According to UNICEF, as of July 2019, more than 500,000 Rohingya children were refugees in Bangladesh in dire sanitary conditions, exposed to the risk of violence, exploitation and abuse of all kinds. Since the 1990s, many Rohingya children born in Myanmar have not received any birth certificates, in full violation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Myanmar has also signed. A denial of civil rights that makes it impossible to obtain identity documents, to have access to health care and education and that also creates obstacles in access to refugee status, thus risking creating a generation of ghost children. The European Union must therefore take firm action to ensure that the Rohingya people fully respect fundamental rights.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On Monday, a report by independent UN experts was published, which found very disturbing information on the situation of the Rohingya population in Myanmar. The threat of genocide of this part of the population that is still in the country seems to be greater than ever. The report's authors also conclude that so far the Government of Myanmar has done nothing to break the circle of violence.  Therefore, the international community, led by the European Union, the UN and humanitarian organisations, must take joint, coordinated action to put strong pressure on those responsible for crimes and persecution. They must be held accountable and brought to justice for their actions. In addition, humanitarian organisations and human rights organisations should be provided with access to the country as soon as possible so that they can provide assistance to those in need and monitor the situation on the ground.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, we come to a subject that is repeatedly on our desks. We are talking about oming people, humiliating them, violating fundamental human rights and committing crimes against humanity. Today, more than 600 000 people are at risk from acts that actually find themselves on the brink of genocide. This is an unprecedented situation and I think that we must firstly help Bangladesh, which hosts 1 million people on its territory, in cooperation with ASEAN. Of course, we must call for immediate assistance for refugees, an investigation into these crimes, and for swift action by the European institutions, because in the negotiations with Myanmar, our voice must be heard unequivocally and that these crimes against humanity will be investigated and the culprits driven to justice.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it has been over two years since the horrible events in the Rakhine State of Myanmar forced more than 750 000 Rohingya to flee to Bangladesh. There are now more than one million Rohingya refugees in Cox’s Bazar, making it the largest refugee camp in the world. This is a major refugee crisis with a significant risk of radicalisation inside the camps. The situation inside the camps is deteriorating. More than 500 000 children remain without access to education. The prospects for a rapid return of the refugees into Myanmar, in a safe, dignified and voluntary manner, are increasingly unlikely. This was shown by the failure of the recent second attempt for the repatriation of 3 450 refugees, since no one agreed to return to Myanmar due to the lack of conditions conducive for returns. The situation, in addition to being an urgent humanitarian crisis, is evolving into a longer-term political and security challenge. Therefore, we need to intensify discussions on the prospects for refugees, the Cox’s Bazar security situation, the livelihood and education opportunities in the camps, the access to health and justice, the impact on the host communities and, of course, the Joint Response Plan funding. The European Union will continue to call for sustainable solutions for the Rohingya, and for the Myanmar authorities to ensure that conditions are met for safe, dignified and voluntary returns. This can be achieved only by implementing the recommendations of the Advisory Commission on Rakhine State, which the Government of Myanmar has endorsed. These issues were raised with the Myanmar Government at the Human Rights Dialogue held in Yangon in June 2019, co-chaired by the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Eamon Gilmore. Within the ongoing Everything But Arms enhanced monitoring, and all relevant bilateral meetings, the European Union is urging Myanmar to contribute to the creation of conditions conducive to the safe, voluntary and dignified return of Rohingya refugees to their place of origin. At the same time, the European Union will continue advocating for the accountability of those who have committed serious abuses of human rights. The Union has already imposed restrictive measures on 14 individuals and will continue to review regularly the sanctions regime. In conclusion, the European Union will continue to help alleviate the plight of the Rohingya in Bangladesh and will keep engaging with the Myanmar authorities to facilitate their return.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The situation of the Rohingya is a major humanitarian crisis, with 740,000 Rohingya fleeing to Bangladesh and some 276,000 living in camps.  Beyond the emotion naturally aroused by this drama, it is important to address this issue in all its aspects, without denying, in particular, the growing influence of radical Islam on this population. Didn't the very leader of the Islamic State in 2014 call the Rakhine region a key to jihad?  It is clear that the European Union, which provides development aid, humanitarian aid and trade preferences to Myanmar, has some say in human rights violations in that country. They are not only Rohingya, but also Christians, who, according to a 2016 report by the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom, are also suffering a number of vexations.  Last July, a Protestant pastor who testified to U.S. President Donald Trump was also reportedly prosecuted in his country. It is therefore all of these elements that should be considered without bias, and with the support of victims at heart.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Iran, notably the situation of women’s rights defenders and imprisoned EU dual nationals (2019/2823(RSP)).

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Mr President, I pay tribute to the women of Iran, to their courage, resolve and determination, not only in the fight for women’s rights, but also in speaking out in defence of the whole society against the regime. One of the major opposition movements in Iran, the National Council of Resistance of Iran, is led by a woman as well. Recently, many women were sentenced to a long time in prison for just protesting against the compulsory wearing of the hijab, but also women with dual nationality, both EU and Iranian, as well, arm in arm with men, are suffering because of persecution there. We appeal for their immediate release.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Many of you are certainly familiar with this tradition of giving flowers to women on International Women's Day, 8 March. It is a peaceful sign for women's rights, which I must say is sometimes too peaceful for myself. Actually – because on 8 March this year, women in Iran, in Tehran, gave flowers in the Metro. In Tehran, the first and last compartments are reserved for women in the metro, and three women took off their veils there and expressed their concerns very clearly. You said: I hope that one day we will be able to march together on the streets of Tehran in Iran, with and without a veil, because there is enough space in Iran for all Iranians. A video shared on social media shows women hugging with and without veils as there is applause. The tension and also a feeling of awakening are really felt. And what was the Iranian regime's reaction? Incarceration, harassment, imprisonment up to 24 years. And that is not the only case. Nasrin Sotudeh, who received the Sakharov Prize from us here in Parliament, was herself sentenced to 33 years and 148 lashes for defending women like the one in the Metro in court. These punishments show us one thing very clearly: the Iranian regime feels threatened by these courageous women. Yes, the situation in the region is truly complicated, and it has become even more complicated in recent days. But I think that it is precisely when good and evil are not so easy, that we must stand by the people who stand up for human rights, who are fighting against discrimination against women in Iran, such as women in the Metro, against discrimination such as an unjust divorce system, such as sexual violence. And there is so much other injustice. If people's rights are being disregarded elsewhere, then we must not remain silent here in this House. That is why let us sign together afterwards for this resolution and for the women of Iran!

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Last week was filled with reports of Sahar Khodayari's horrific and terribly unnecessary death as a result of the injuries after setting himself on fire. She did so in desperation after being arrested and risked brutal imprisonment when she wanted to see a football match, something that is so natural and that all people would be entitled to. It is such a terribly tragic event and my solidarity and the solidarity of our Parliament with her family is there today. We're thinking about her. The debate today is about the situation of women's rights campaigners and about imprisoned EU citizens with dual citizenship in Iran.
