We are now sending a clear message that the situation of women fighting for human rights in Iran must be improved. Many have been imprisoned simply because they have stood up to discrimination. We are talking about cases where it is human rights defenders, women's rights defenders, lawyers, journalists, trade union activists and environmentalists who are imprisoned without trial year after year, month after month, with great suffering as a result. We deal with the cases of Mojgan Keshavarz, Nasrin Sotoudeh and Narges Mohammadi. We reiterate our clear call for the immediate release of Ahmad Reza Jalali and other detainees with dual citizenship and for fair treatment to be obtained.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: Author. - Mr President, we are debating an Emergency Resolution to call for the immediate release of all women activists convicted in Iran and also for the release of citizens of dual European and Iranian nationality, who are now in dramatic conditions in Iran's prisons, without communication or access to their lawyers or their families. The last three women convicted were for a video that went viral on March 8, in which, taking off their veils, they handed out flowers and told women that they wished they could walk together in Iran, some with a veil, some without him, but as a result of a free and own decision. This was her crime, a crime considered an attack on national security, for which they have been sentenced to more than twenty-three years in prison, in a trial without guarantees, without having access to the choice of lawyer. The Iranian authorities have opened a real campaign of harassment and persecution against women activists, against lawyers defending their rights, against journalists who broadcast their actions. And they have said that they will move forward, that they feel that they have been living in a prison for too long: what their country is to them. They will defend their right, their freedom and the future of their daughters. That is why it is important today that this Parliament sends a very clear message. On the one hand, to the Commission, to tell it that, in the political dialogue with Iran, the European Union must have a political priority, which is the defence of Iranian human rights, women and girls. But also a very clear message to Iranian women, to tell them that they are not alone, that the European Parliament is with them and that we will be with all those who are now resisting, in prisons and on the streets.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: author. – Mr President, the Iranian authorities continue to criminalise human rights activism. Journalists, lawyers and activists are constantly facing harassment, arrests and prosecution for their peaceful work. With this resolution, the European Parliament is calling upon Iran to suppress all these sentences and immediately and unconditionally release all human rights defenders and all EU-Iran dual nationals who are arbitrarily detained. Three Iranian women appeared in a video while protesting against the compulsory wearing of veils. The protest was peaceful and advocated for women’s right to choose whether to wear the hijab or not. These three women have been convicted and sentenced to between 16 and 23 years’ imprisonment. The authorities reasoned that they were acting against national security and promoting moral corruption and prostitution. This case is a clear example of an extremely disproportionate punishment. Moreover, these women were arrested although they were solely exercising their right of freedom of expression – one of the core rights of every human being. In another case, an Iranian woman set herself on fire in protest at her arrest because she wanted to watch a football match in a stadium. Besides this violation of women’s rights, the joint resolution also reacts to Iranian measures taken against several EU-Iran dual nationals. These persons have been arrested on the basis of vague or unspecified charges and sentenced without a fair trial. It is clear that Iran is severely violating human rights, and we – as a democratic body that represents those imprisoned European citizens – have a moral duty to support them and to react in a resolute manner. This House is constituted to protect all European citizens wherever they are. Iran is one of the founding states of the United Nations, and has ratified multiple legally binding treaties under international law, focusing on respect for human rights. However, reality shows that they don’t respect these obligations. With this resolution, we urge the Iranian authorities to halt their repressive actions and to implement the internationally agreed standards. Colleagues, please show your support for these arbitrarily imprisoned women and European Union citizens, and send a strong message to the authorities in Iran.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am probably one of the few Members here who got to know the human rights activist and lawyer Nasrin Sotudeh in Tehran – in 2013 after her dismissal. Three years later, she was convicted again and arrested again in 2018. In March 2019, she received a 33-year prison sentence for supporting women who refused to wear headscarves and protested against it. In the face of such disgrace, we must not remain silent! No matter what else happens in Iran, we must not remain silent! International solidarity needs every single one of these arrested women– even those whose names we do not know. I would like to say one thing to the Iranian Government: we cannot set aside progress towards civilisation in the long term, we cannot stop it. You can delay it, you can imprison its representatives, you can silence them – you can do anything, but the idea of freedom and equality, which you cannot eradicate – neither by law nor by force. This is because it makes us human, it justifies our universal rights. Whether in my hometown of Dresden, Hong Kong or Tehran – the future of Iran is the women, no one else, and a revolutionary leader will not change that.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Islamic Republic of Iran is clearly a mass violator of human rights, and women are particularly targeted. Crimes punished there that are not crimes in our world. Traditionally Shia societies prided themselves on being more liberal than some other creeds, but today Iran is a country which executes one of the greatest numbers of its citizens, while its justice system doesn’t meet any criteria that we would recognise. Medieval mullahs pass harsh sentences on people who, according to our standards, have not committed crimes at all. I think I am right in saying that Iran has the death penalty for homosexuality, for example. So I would like to associate myself fully with all the voices that have been heard here in defence of the victims of Iran’s unfair justice system, and particularly the women who have been targeted by it. But Iran is also a geopolitical challenge today. We have just had attacks on Saudi oil facilities, and I don’t think those drones and those missiles were built by some rebels in the mountains. That equipment came from somewhere, and Saudi Arabia has made a case for it being supplied by the Islamic Republic of Iran. A few weeks ago, we had an attack on tankers anchored in the mouth of the Strait of Hormuz. It looks to me like the theocratic regime is trying to provoke the United States into an armed attack, and I just hope that neither the United States nor we allow ourselves to be provoked, because we have been provoked before and I don’t like the consequences.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: On behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear Chairman, it is unacceptable that women are threatened with imprisonment for trying to watch a game in a stadium, a long sentence of imprisonment for peacefully protesting the imposed style of flower giving on Women's Day. Prison sentences are also further punished by being a slogging. Of particular concern are the frequent arrests and charges against women, often European Union nationals, who are fighting for the right to choose and lifestyle they want. Even when faced with such improper charges and punishments, all inmates must be entitled to counsel and health care in prisons. Fundamental human rights must not be alienated under the pretext of different traditional and cultural customs. They must be inaliething, no matter where they are demanded. Iran needs to finally bring its legislation in line with the human rights conventions of which it is a signatory, and the European Union must actively keep this problem on the agenda of all bilateral and multilateral relations with Iran.

name: Luisa PORRITT
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, my constituent, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a dual EU—Iranian national, has been unlawfully imprisoned for more than 1 200 days. Having initially been refused access to a trial for months, she then faced one by a kangaroo court that was neither free nor fair. In prison Nazanin has often been deprived of proper medical assistance. She is no longer allowed international phone calls and can only see her five-year-old daughter, Gabriella, once a month. This treatment is tantamount to state hostage-taking. Nazanin has previously gone on hunger strikes and has warned she may do so again if she continues to be deprived of her fundamental human rights.  Her husband, Richard, has recently pointed out that the dominance of Brexit means her case has fallen off the UK Government’s agenda. As Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson also contributed to making her situation worse and has failed to meet with Richard since becoming Prime Minister. In circumstances such as these, the EU must make its voice heard. Nazanin is not alone. Other EU dual nationals suffer from violations of their human rights in Iranian prisons and are denied free and fair trials. Colleagues, it is our duty to stand up for their protection at home and abroad. Please support this urgency.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the situation of women in Iran is becoming increasingly worrying and this Parliament cannot fail to denounce it. One of the last alarming cases is the tragic death of the twenty-nine-year-old Sahar Jodayarí, who decided to set himself on fire in the face of a possible six-month prison sentence for attempting to enter a football match disguised as a man. Iran is the only country in the world that forbids women from entering stadiums, but of course this is by no means the only discrimination. Since January last year, at least thirty-two people have been arrested, and ten imprisoned for protesting against the wearing of the mandatory veil, which is a manifest violation of their right to manifest themselves as an exercise of freedom of expression. We therefore demand the release of all persons arbitrarily detained and imprisoned for exercising their fundamental rights. Moreover, Iranian women remain strongly discriminated against on issues of personal status related to marriage, divorce, inheritance and the issue of children, and are marginalized economically. Discrimination in the public and private sectors must come to an end. We hope that our call today, from here, will help the European Union and its Member States to prioritize the protection of human rights defenders in Iran. We all want the iran nuclear deal to work and be feasibility, and I think we are making a lot of effort from the European Union to make that happen. The drums of war must be far away and we must put all our energy into making that work, but that must be closely linked to the defense of human rights in the country. We can't put that aside because now we need the nuclear plan to succeed. Both must go hand in hand, and that is why we are also asking, in an idea that feminism permeates the whole of the European Union's foreign policy, that women's rights in Iran be prioritized in all our relations with the country.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, perhaps not everyone knows that women in Iran, until the 1970s, were like us, dressed like us and had access to education just like us. Then at some point, in 1979, the regime arrived, the Islamic Republic was created and, in the name of religion, women's rights were totally trampled underfoot, bringing them into the Middle Ages. Consider that the women's national basketball, soccer or volleyball teams now play with the veil. Then someone will come to tell you that the veil is a choice, but it is not! The veil is oppression, it's submission, women don't want to wear headscarves, they don't want to cover themselves. We are firmly on the side of the activists who, on a daily basis, work to defend rights and shout what is happening, somehow trying to combat the subjugation of women in those countries. Europe, I have to say, too often out of good will, or even a little out of fear, has been silent, it has not intervened in all those Islamic countries that constantly submit women's rights. I do not think we can turn our heads, we must fight for women and we absolutely cannot remain silent.

name: Witold Jan WASZCZYKOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as a former Polish ambassador to Iran, I have to say that I’m not very happy that we have to discuss today this misbehaviour by the Iranian authorities. I would prefer to discuss the contribution of Iranian culture to our civilisation. In a time of growing tension in the Persian Gulf, we expect Iran to play a more constructive role in this region. Especially, we expect that Iran will respect the human rights of Iranian citizens and those living in or visiting the country. We also expect Iran to stop its policy of arbitrary detentions and immediately and unconditionally to release all the EU dual nationals and human rights defenders, especially women’s rights promoters. Finally, we hope that Iran will refrain from offensive policies in the region. If Iran truly wishes to keep friendly relations with the European Union, it needs to change its policy urgently and to stick to international norms and standards.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, while we know that women play a prominent role in Iran in a way that would put Saudi Arabia to shame, we also know that Iran has no defence on many of these issues relating to women’s rights, and things must change. But to erase all mention of the illegal US sanctions against Iran is to ignore the world that these women and children must live in. We all know that economic sanctions hit the poor. It’s a slow form of torture to hit the weak – children and women – the most. To claim to champion the human rights of a people, while refusing even to acknowledge, let alone criticise, a brutal economic sanctions regime against the same people speaks volumes about the political nature of that concern for human rights. Iran is under siege from many international players at the moment and we need to work with them to help them out of the impasse. It’s in our interest too. The motion, as it stands, is just another political weapon against Iran and, unless our amendments are accepted, my Group will be opposing this motion.

name: Belinda DE LUCY
text: – Mr President, I’d like to first say I stand with those courageous women peacefully protesting for their rights in Iran. But as Iran grows bolder in its provocations, it appears the EU’s deal with Iran is failing in its objectives. Even its most important signatory, the United States, has pulled out. British citizens are the subject of kidnapping, solitary confinement and barbarity. Our citizens have become pawns in this geopolitical game and yet the EU remains the biggest global champion of the Iran nuclear deal with cynical commercial undertones. Iran benefits from EU investment while it continues to prop up terrorist groups in the region. And while the EU rightly speaks about the human rights atrocities, what does speaking do? It is sanctions, not words, that are needed or Iran will be emboldened further. But the names of just some of those languishing in Iranian prison cells need to be spoken. Our citizens who live in fear and isolation right now, real people like Jolie King and Mark Firkin, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, Kylie Moore-Gilbert, Anoosheh Ashoori and Morad Tahbaz. It’s time to act now.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, once again Iran is and is the protagonist of a debate always under the same common denominator: the violation of human rights. Journalists, human rights defenders, minorities, the disabled, women, activists, people with dual nationality, all of them suffer harassment, unfair trials, torture, arbitrary arrests, and this simply for doing their job and for defending human rights. They cannot do so without threats and without harassment or intimidation. There are many cases , mentioned here – of these tortures and of people who have suffered. I would like to focus on the case of the Blue Girl, in Sahar Jodayarí; that girl in blue, twenty-nine, whose crime was to be a woman. Passionate about football, dressed in blue, the color of her team, Esteghlal, disguised herself as a man to go to the stadium to see her favorite team. But their country's rulers forbid and do not allow women to go to stadiums—the only country in the world. She immolated heeded in the court of Tehran on the understanding that she would be imprisoned. Their only crime," as I said, is being a woman in a country where men determine women's lives and deprive them of their basic human rights. Heartbreaking is tragic death, as heartbreaking is the Iranian authorities' terrible contempt for women's rights. Since the beginning of the revolution, more than 120,000 people have been executed. Journalists Without Borders says Iran is the world's largest prison for women journalists. We need a quiet response to so much oppression and that is why Commissioner Thyssen, who has a special sensitivity, will help us shout a cry for peace, a cry for help. Sahar's death cannot in any case be in vain. Iranian women are brave, there are many, and determined to fight to conquer their rights. We can't leave them alone. They are, really, the true Islamic revolution. And Europe must show its award for peace and be by its side.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, discrimination against women in Iran is a daily reality. When a woman, and I am thinking especially of Sahar Khodayari, prefers to self-immolate rather than be tried by a revolutionary court for daring to set foot in a football stadium, we understand how women are deprived of the essential foundations of their fundamental rights. A society that does not guarantee the rights of half its population cannot grow, cannot claim development. Unfortunately, Iran is not unique, and we could cite all the states that violate women's rights. The list would be long and I would need more than a minute to be able to quote them. But Iran is a partner of the Union. The Union defended, was the initiator of the nuclear agreement with Iran. It may seem incongruous to some to talk about women's rights when talking about a nuclear deal. Yet the Union must seize all the instruments at its disposal to combat the greatest injustice in the world, which is to deprive half of humanity of its most basic rights, namely the right of women.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Mr President, the state of human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran has often been criticised. Freedom of speech and expression is severely restricted, and it is no secret that the Iranian authorities have been engaging in a severe clampdown on journalists and advocates of human rights.  This imprisonment and the level of unfair trials we see are particularly predominant amongst the ethnic minority groups in Iran, including the Ahvaz Arabs, the Kurds and the Baloch populations, and these groups form a substantial part of the population.  Now Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe is a dual EU-Iranian national. She is a British citizen. She has been unlawfully imprisoned in Iran, having been refused a trial or access to any legal assistance for months. She was then found guilty of espionage after a very, very short and unfair trial. I met her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, recently when we shared a platform in Geneva. He struck me as a good man of deep integrity, who is courageously leading a campaign to try to free his wife.  In the more geopolitical sense, in 2018 the US withdrew its support for the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and imposed sanctions, whereas the European Union has maintained its support for the agreement. Has not this been a clear sign to Iran that the EU can be a potential friend? I urge Iran to immediately release all those named in this resolution. I also want to urge Iran to rethink its policies and approach to human rights, and particularly freedom of speech and expression. In this way, we can create the foundation for a normalisation of relations between Iran and the EU.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, yes, we must condemn and denounce all those countries that oppress women: Iran, of course, as mentioned in this resolution, but also Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. How can we not remember the persecutions suffered by Asia Bibi? The reality is that all the countries that have enshrined Sharia law as a fundamental legal text oppress women. It is the use of this text that must be strongly condemned. Mrs von der Leyen has chosen to appoint a Commissioner to protect our European way of life. One of the first protections will be to denounce this text, Sharia law, so that no community claims its use in Europe.  We will vote on that. It is better to make a small step, a small step, rather than no text. But for want of naming the real problem, we remain facilitators of the oppression of women in too many countries.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Mr President, she liked soccer, maybe she was in love with someone, and enjoyed specific scents or food. Her name is Sahar Khodayari. She was also known as the Blue Girl, the colour of her favourite soccer team. Facing a jail sentence for trying to watch a soccer game, which is forbidden for women in her country – as another Flemish Iranian, Darya Safai, has been telling the world – the 29—year—old Iranian set herself on fire two weeks ago in front of the Islamic Revolutionary Court of Tehran. In Iran, human rights defenders, or people like her who just want to enjoy freedom, face harassment, prosecution and detention. Protecting women’s rights is not a crime. Since January 2018, 32 people have been arrested in Iran, and at least 10 imprisoned, for protesting against the mandatory wearing of the hijab. The compulsory dress code is a violation of human rights and women’s dignity. In the past three years, 30 EU dual nationals have been unjustly arrested – like, for example, Professor Ahmad Reza Jalali who was also a visiting professor at the Free University Brussels (VUB). After all the resolutions, Council conclusions and so on, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy stressed, earlier this year, that dialogue is the only way, but it’s not enough. It was not for Khodayari: she is dead because she liked soccer and was 29. It was not for Jalali: he’s in jail and sick. Many others are threatened.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: – Mr President; "I will make you all suffer": these were the words of the judge who condemned three Iranian women for peacefully protesting against the obligatory wearing of the Islamic veil. Sentenced to long prison terms in a trial without guarantees and previously beaten and tortured. Since January 2018 dozens of women have been arrested in Iran for protesting against the mandatory wearing of the veil, and more than fifty people arrested in their fight for women's rights. Compulsory hijab is pure gender apartheid, a discriminatory imposition that marks the lives of thousands of girls and women. But there is no culture, national identity or religious belief that can be used to violate our dignity and our rights. Not to get dressed or undressed. We want the Iranian authorities to be encouraged to overturn convictions and release arbitrarily detained defenders; to ensure their access to justice and to protect their right to freedom of expression, demonstration and non-discrimination. We don't think women who cover themselves are submissive and women who don't are empowered. What we want is for our bodies to be no longer used as religious symbols and patriotic flags in any corner of the world.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Mr President, every day Nazanin Zaghari—Ratcliffe, Aras Amiri and other UK citizens languish in Iranian jails is a tragedy for them and their families. The EU and our Parliament is complicit in this tragedy: our hands are stained. The EU promised Iran that it would get round American sanctions. Fourteen months on, the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (INSTEX) is still an empty promise. EU sanctions led to UK Marines in Gibraltar impounding an Iranian oil tanker, only for the EU to demand it be freed to carry on its sanction—busting voyage to Syria. When the UK asked the EU for support to protect shipping in the Straits of Hormuz it refused. The EU’s desperation to have the foreign policy trappings of a national state is like watching Pinocchio wanting to be a real boy. It’s too easily led, it’s full of deceit and it has no conscience. Can you imagine the disaster if it had its own army? And what about this Parliament. I’m a member of the Parliament’s Delegation for relations with Iran. I wrote to Parliament in July asking for the Iranian delegation to meet urgently. I had no response. I tried again: zero response. Seventy days have passed in this session and still the Parliament’s Delegation for relations with Iran has not met: 70 days rotting in jail for Nazanin, Aras and many more. It’s a tragedy. Our hands are stained.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Mr President, women’s lives are under threat in many different countries, we know this, but in Iran we’ve had the Iranian Revolutionary Courts in recent months substantially ratchet up their punishments for even modest peaceful acts of protest by women, human rights defenders in particular. For what? For being a woman, for not wearing a hijab, or headscarf, watching a football match – or trying to – at a stadium, handing-out flowers on International Women’s Day.  The women, many of them with dual nationalities that are EU, are being targeted with dire consequences. For example women journalists on BBC Persia are subjected to sexualised slander, women human rights defenders are denied access to legal representation. They are arrested at peaceful Labour Day marches. There is a long list in this resolution of names, including Nazanin, as has been mentioned many times here already, of extreme punishments, of years and years in prisons, lack of medical care and lack of access to legal representatives. Now these human rights offences are of the highest order, and we must call it out and we must do something about it. Iran must cease and desist and we must make sure that women have their full rights enforced wherever occurrences of human rights offences take place.

name: Christophe GRUDLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to salute the courage of all women's rights defenders in Iran, who peacefully denounce the continuing repression they face because of the exercise of their right to freedom of expression and their opposition to the compulsory veil.  In 2018, in Iran, about 100 women were arrested for such actions. They are still in custody. At least five of them have dual nationality, the European Union-Iran. Considered enemies of the state, they are denied access to justice. We call on the Iranian judiciary to release them immediately and unconditionally. Finally, we call on our Member States in Tehran to do everything possible to obtain a complete list of prisoners with dual European Union-Iran nationality, to support and protect them, including through prison visits, public statements and diplomatic efforts to secure their swift release.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, discrimination, intimidation and repression against women in Iran have increased since Iranian women decided to spread the abuses of the so-called 'moral police', the arrests, abuses and beatings to which they are subjected every day throughout the web. Europe, which is based on values of freedom and responsibility, cannot accept these violations of human rights, practised by an archaic and hypocritical political system that uses the Islamic religion to impose its power. This fanaticism is also spreading the subculture of abuse on women in European cities, with the complicity of a short-sighted left-wing politician who is fighting for the right to a headscarf in Europe as if it were a privilege rather than an imposition. We cannot resign ourselves to the alibi of cultural diversity. Safeguarding our values of civilisation is an act that must be imposed. Europe's solidarity with Iranian women must therefore extend to all women of Islamic religion in the West, because their freedom is the freedom and security of our future.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Iranian people have a long, wonderful history. It is an ancient nation, and the more we should demand respect for women. Isn't it a paradox - I say this as a historian - that forty or fifty years ago, during the time of Shah Reza Pahlawi, women in Iran had more rights than they do now. There's been a setback here, it's sad. Of course, when we talk about women's rights in Iran, we should particularly listen to the women who have been in Iran, from Iran, and bear witness to some truth about what is going on there. In the European Parliament, too, we have had a number of conferences involving such women, including Mrs Rajawi. Let us also remember those who are Iranians for Iran and citizens of our countries for the Member States of the Union - those who have dual citizenship. We must remember all of them and we must take care of their rights.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the 70% of Iranian women are against the strict dress code in the country. That's according to a study by Iran's State Parliamentary Research Center. More and more women are protesting against laws of forced veiling and defending every woman's right to decide what she wants to wear, without fear of harassment, violence or even imprisonment. Since January 2018, dozens of women's rights activists, including men, have been arrested and treated as criminals. Peaceful protest is a human right and is part of it in every society. Four courageous women – Saba Kord-Afshari, Mojgan Keshavarz, Yasaman Aryani, and Monireh Arabshahi – peacefully protested Iran's discriminatory obfuscation law and were sentenced to 16 to 24 years in prison. This is unacceptable, it is unacceptable. We call for the immediate release of these women's rights activists.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In recent months, the Iranian authorities have taken further steps to exacerbate the repression of women in Iran. In April this year, for example, women's rights activists Mojgan Keshavarz, Monireh Arabshahi and Yasaman Ariyani were arrested after they posted a video of themselves handing out flowers without a veil to passengers on the Iran metro. For this so-called offence – handing out flowers in clothes of their choice – they were sentenced to between 16 and 24 years in prison. The European Parliament must condemn the misogynistic regime in Iran. The EU should always be a crystal clear voice for the human rights and freedoms of girls and women. It's 2019 now! Everyone must have power over their own lives and their own bodies!

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I can't believe your sister is burning herself to death in protest of a regime that has suffocated all her joie de vivre. I can't believe your daughter is sentenced to 20 years in prison just for her refusal to wear a veil. You'd appreciate the support of the outside world. Instead, the world's first feminist government wears a veil on a visit to Iran. On Swedish soil, the Iranian Foreign Minister's refusal to take his female counterpart in hand is accepted. When we Conservatives point out that in Sweden we have taken women's hand since time immemorial, we are dismissed with ignorant claims that Iranians do not take women in hand, which is nonsense.  Women who are oppressed in the name of Islam deserve the wholehearted support of the outside world. That is why we must stand up for Western values in the face of the barbaric regime in Tehran and we must stop wearing the symbol of oppression of women just to please the mullahs!

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Women are massively discriminated against in Almost all areas of society in Iran. This applies, among other things, to the legal system in Iran – Sharia law, which also provides for the death penalty. The clerical dictatorial regime is based on male rule by Islamist fundamentalists and their hatred of women. This specifically excludes gender equality and the rights of minorities and dissidents. The cases of the Iranian activists illustrate the abhorrence of such a system. Decades of imprisonment and dozens of lashes for women who are committed to human rights is unacceptable! All this shows that as long as this clerical dictatorship prevails, in which women are violently oppressed, the conditions for peaceful coexistence of the states in the Middle East do not exist.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, allow me to start by expressing my deepest respect for, and solidarity with, all Iranian human rights defenders. I’m especially touched by the bravery of Iranian women, who choose such a peaceful way to claim their rights, giving flowers to other women in underground trains and discussing their rights. To some extent it reminds me of our peaceful resistance to the Soviet occupation, especially with the Baltic Way – only we achieved freedom, while Iranian colleagues have been sentenced to prison, with sentences of unimaginable length. The impact of continuing human rights violations and the suppression and intimidation of opposition and journalists has long overreached the borders of Iran. It causes regional instability and threatens global security and the economy. I call on the Iranian Government to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with international human rights standards and international instruments ratified by that country. I also urge the Council to review the European position on Iran by considering additional sanctions.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation of women in Iran is extremely difficult. They must fight for fundamental rights. Sstone is one of the methods of execution provided for by Islamic criminal law. When they are raped, they are punished on an equal footing with the rapist. Disenchated and legally forced to wear the hijab, Iranian women need support. Iranian women's rights defenders, including Union citizens, are sentenced to long prison sentences for actions that are not even criminal. The pretext for such sanctions is, for example, contact with representatives of the European Union, the UN or contact with the media.  The Iranian Government is seeking closer relations with the European Union, so it should be called upon to respect human rights, to stop criminalising the defence of women's rights, and to respect the rights of European Union citizens.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Mr President, three Iranian women’s rights activists disappeared and were sentenced to 16 and 22 years in prison. And their crime you ask? Taking the liberty to decide for themselves what to wear. In reality, this is about a regime of men scared of women claiming their rights and demanding equality. This latest incident is not an isolated one. The Iranian regime has a long history of human rights abuses. There have been thousands of sham court cases, many of which even led to the death penalty. Madam Commissioner, I urge you and the High Representative to do everything in your power to have these courageous women’s rights defenders released immediately. No government should arrest and imprison women for what they wear, not in Iran and not in Europe. We don’t need men in power to tell us what to wear.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, what is the meaning of this usual debate in the European Parliament, on Thursday morning, in plenary, about flagrant violations of fundamental rights? To express the priorities and values of the citizenship we represent and to determine the foreign policy of the Commission and the European Union as a whole, with a resolution which, in this case - and is rare - has unanimity in the expression of the condemnation that deserves the systematic and flagrant violation of women's rights and their discrimination in Iran. Scary cases have been commented eloquently: a woman who commits suicide dramatically after attending a football stadium disguised as a man, because she knows she will be convicted; women who suffer inhuman punishment and degrading punishment on a systematic basis. The European Union has made an effort to maintain the Iranian nuclear agreement, exercised its diplomacy, asserting its priorities. This does not diminish, but on the contrary, strengthens moral authority to demand in foreign policy towards Iran the cessation of systematic violation and persecution of women's rights.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, I too stand shoulder to shoulder with women struggling for human rights and equality in Iran. I fully support calling for the release of those women in prison for their political and protest activity to advance women’s rights in Iran, and indeed their right to wear whatever they like. And I absolutely condemn the death penalty, including on those under age. But I have to say that I do find the motion imbalanced at a time when tone is important, at a time when Iran is under siege from many international players. We had somebody come in here today and tell us that Iran is trying to provoke a war with the USA – when it’s the USA which has torn up the nuclear deal, when it is the USA that is crippling the economy of Iran and causing immense harm to women and children. So, in that sense, we all know Iran has to change – they’re not the only ones – but of course they know this and I welcome the fact that there is now an equal number of women as clerics in the Iranian Parliament. I’m looking forward to a time when there are more, but this motion won’t help unless we include the amendments on the sanctions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I just wanted to concur with what has been said by many speakers. The situation of women in Iran is unacceptable, and particularly from the point of view of the European Union, when I was a member of the Iranian delegation in the last mandate, we worked very hard to keep the nuclear accord in place, and the European Union stuck its neck out in that regard, but that must be reciprocated. As has been said, by particularly allowing women the freedom they deserve, and as one MEP said, men in Iran should not be telling women what to wear. I also concur with my colleague, Clare Daly, on the obligations of the United States in relation to Iran, and the nuclear accord. It was they who pulled out of it, and that was done despite the fact that there was an agreement done with the previous president, President Obama, so that in itself is also a cause for condemnation.

name: Ben HABIB
text: – Mr President, I’m absolutely staggered by the debate I’ve heard this morning. The greatest ally the European Union Member States have had in history is the United States of America. When the USA rightly imposed sanctions on Iran, the European Union actively went about trying to undermine those sanctions by setting up a subsidiary, a special purpose vehicle to step around the sanctions. Thankfully that failed. In June this year, the USA asked for support in the Straits of Hormuz, and EU Member States turned it down. You won’t forget that, in July, a British ship was taken by the Iranians, something which might not have happened had the EU supported American efforts. And now we have all this virtue-signalling in this inept Chamber, and no action taken by the European Union to support the greatest ally this country has ever had. And, one more thing, the EU does not put enough money into NATO and yet it is putting money into a new European defence force. It’s completely wrong. Get your priorities right. Get behind the United States of America.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I’ve met Richard Ratcliffe, the husband of dual national, Nazanin Zaghari—Ratcliffe, who’s led the three—year campaign for her release from prison in Iran, even going on hunger strike earlier this year in solidarity with his wrongfully incarcerated wife. Nazanin is alone in a country that refuses to recognise her dual citizenship, forces her into solitary confinement and holds the threat of a second trial and conviction over her head. The appalling conditions she endures are undeniably inhumane and must come to an end. Nazanin is a prisoner alongside UK resident Aras Amiri, who was jailed last year while visiting family in Iran, whilst dual British—Iranian national, Kamil Ahmadi – a hugely respected academic and campaigner dedicated to ending FGM – was recently detained in Iran on unknown charges. Dual nationals, European citizens, must not be forgotten, but neither should they be put in further danger through careless words. And I refer here to the unfortunate and misleading statements made by Boris Johnson when he was Foreign Secretary. We deserve better than this.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our commitment to support human rights defenders, including women’s rights defenders, is a fundamental part of our human rights policy. Unfortunately, in too many countries, including Iran, women continue to face threats and abuse because they are human rights defenders or simply because they are women. They receive defamatory comments and slander. They face hatred, harassment, intimidation and incitement to violence, often of a sexual nature, or they face imprisonment for standing up for their basic rights. In this context, I would like to express how deeply saddened I am by the fate of Sahar Khodayari, who earlier this month set herself on fire after learning that she faced a prison sentence for trying to attend a football match, and who died in the hospital from her wounds. Her tragic death is the heart-breaking aftermath of an appalling contempt for women’s rights. No woman should fear imprisonment for attending a sporting event.  Every year, on 8 May, the international community marks International Women’s Day. For the European Union, this is a time to pay tribute to acts of courage and determination by ordinary women around the world who have played an extraordinary role in the history of their countries and communities. In the joint statement that the EU published on 8 May this year, we stated that we are committed to giving all women and girls equal access to health services, education and economic empowerment and opportunities to shape their own future. We will never stop fighting for true equality for all, inside and outside the European Union, to make sure that progress achieved is not undone. Our commitment to support human rights defenders, including women’s rights defenders, also applies to our work in Iran. In the context of the regular, high-level political dialogue with Iran that aims to advance bilateral cooperation in a number of areas of mutual interest, the European Union has been consistently raising issues of human rights. We have regularly engaged with the authorities to demand that human rights defenders, including women, must not be subjected to harassment or detention.  We have been vocal in this demand, for instance in the case of the 2012 Sakharov Prize laureate Nasrin Sotoudeh, who was sentenced to long periods of imprisonment because of her advocacy for fundamental human rights. And we continue to be vocal, including in international fora such as the United Nations Human Rights Council. The rights of women and girls are also likely to figure prominently during Iran’s upcoming Universal Periodic Review in November. I am acutely aware that the focus of this debate also extends to the situation of EU dual nationals imprisoned in Iran. There again I would like to be clear: the practice of detaining and imprisoning individuals, such as the UK Iranian citizen Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, solely on account of their nationality is contrary to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Iran has ratified and is bound to uphold. Iran’s continued practice of detaining dual nationals clearly breaches the commitment that no one shall be subject to arbitrary arrest or detention. As the European Union, we will continue to call for the release of all EU-Iranian dual nationals and all Iranian human rights defenders. We also call on Iran to ensure that no individual is detained arbitrarily, and that detainees are not subject to any form of mistreatment. Detainees should also have timely access to a lawyer of their own choosing, and to adequate medical care. Honourable Members, thank you for this debate. I can tell you that we are encouraged by the attention paid to these issues by the Members of the European Parliament and we will continue our efforts to work together with you to support human rights defenders across the world. (Applause)

Und nun eine Bitte an alle Antisemiten in diesem Haus, also vor allem an Grüne, Linke und Sozialdemokraten: Stehen Sie auf, widersprechen Sie bitte meinem Antrag, damit wir wissen, mit wem wir es hier zu tun haben.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Madam President, thank you very well Let us do it one by one. First of all, Mr Fest's oral amendment, and then the related request for a roll-call vote. I would definitely do that. But first of all, the question is: are there any objections to the oral amendment? That does not seem to be the case. I shall then put this oral amendment to the vote. (Protest calls in the hall) Ladies and gentlemen! We are still a very young Parliament. We have the opportunity to table oral amendments. The Rules of Procedure do not provide for a debate on these oral amendments, nor for any requests to speak, but only for the President to ask whether there are any objections to the date of amendment. And if 40 Members rise up, then the oral amendment cannot be put to the vote. If there are not 40 Members, it will be put to the vote, also without further debate. Mr Fest, I would like to be fair: do you agree that I should ask a second time who has objections to the oral amendment, because colleagues are obviously not yet familiar with the procedures? (Mr Fest expressed his opposition) Mr Fest thinks – as I can understand – that it is not a fair practice to ask twice. That is why I am now taking the motion to the vote by roll call. I have allowed the roll-call vote to be taken; we will carry out them. The honourable Member has tabled an oral amendment and, at the same time, has asked for a roll-call vote. I allow them.
