We will get it all done. That concludes the vote.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am glad that the European Parliament has clearly opposed the patentability of new species of plants and animals created by biological methods, that is, classical breeding. We have thus sent a clear signal to both the Council and the Commission to work to clarify this legal complication. It is important to influence the European Patent Office to restore legal certainty and the interest of breeders, farmers and the public. The opposite would make it impossible to use biological materials for further research and breeding. It is not in any of our interests that otherwise freely available biological resources should be subject to strict industrial patent protection as in other sectors. For this reason, I supported the resolution and appeal to the other Member States to actively help to resolve the current unclear legal situation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, thank you for giving the floor and orderly in this House. I want to start by clarifying my explanation on this point. I supported it because, in my opinion, the patentability of biological plants or animals resulting from certain breeding is indeed over the edge. The public interest clearly shows that such patentability should not be admissible. This Parliament has always advocated the protection of intellectual property. Copyright protection, other rights related to copyright, is our own. On the other hand, I think that this must have clearly defined boundaries, and the public interest in the availability of the use of biological resources is clear. That is why I also supported this motion for a resolution as a clear instruction to the European Patent Office and also to strengthen legal certainty.

name: Sheila RITCHIE
text: – Mr President, the issue of patenting living organisms actually came as an entire shock to me. OK, my prior naivety. I’m gobsmacked that resources and seeds that have been developed or passed on as traditional or public knowledge can be turned into knowledge owned by large corporations. It’s vital that that knowledge is available to small farmers and plant breeders.  The patenting of natural plant developments, in addition to allowing corporations to own knowledge, making it inaccessible to farmers, often conflicts with indigenous knowledge and the rights of indigenous people, the sustainability of local ecosystems and even the ability of nations to provide food security and to protect the global environment. Large transnational corporations effectively steal the knowledge of natural plants used for generations by local people without their knowledge and without their consent. The farmers find the only way to get it is to buy it.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: . – Mr President, plant diversity is an excellent resource for the creation of new viable varieties. But, when creating new varieties for the production of plant food, managing climate change, it is not enough. The latest advances in science and advanced technologies are needed. Patented plant material may be necessary for the production of prophetic safe food. However, the patent holder may refuse to license the use of such material in the development of other new plant varieties. Such provisions shall not apply to the granting of legal protection to plant varieties where plant varieties may be used for further breeding and improvement. Breeders should not be dependent on the patent owner in relation to the patented invention of the plant. I therefore support the provision that parts of plant varieties, genes, should not be able to grant patents, so that the patent office has clear guidelines. Thanks.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the advances in plant breeding and plant technology are the central fact of this generation. We’re becoming better and better at getting more yield out of smaller territory. The result of this is not only that we are able to feed the world in a way that a generation ago would have seemed unimaginable, it is not only that we have disproved all of the dire predictions of mass starvation that were habitually being made in the ‘70s and ‘80s, it is that we are allowing nature to pour back in, we’re allowing for a huge revival of reforestation and of previously endangered species as the territory needed to sustain our population dwindles. The European Union should be at the forefront of this technology, but as so often a combination of luddite politicians and vested interests mean that we’re cutting ourselves off, particularly from advances in genetic modification. Britain, I hope, will be outside the EU at the forefront of this technology, but I hope our neighbours will rush to follow us in due course.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, this one-sided resolution does not in any case honour the memory of the victims of totalitarianism. First of all, it is clear that the memory of the last world war is now being hijacked for political purposes, because the European Union cannot establish its legitimacy on any popular support.  What could be more opportune, in fact, when from election to election, the rejection of peoples is asserted, than to cling to the pink legend of a European Union guaranteeing peace on the continent. In reality, the Europeans owe their liberation, not to a camarilla of Brussels officials, but to the United States, and, to use General de Gaulle's words, to eternal Russia.  The denial of history that permeates every line of this text will never erase the blood of the 20 million Or so Russians sacrificed for Europe to live. Thus, this resolution falls under the same rewrites of history which it purports to denounce as specific to dictatorial regimes, an observation which challenges us as to the nature of this Union whose authoritarian drift is becoming more and more evident.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Colleagues, I supported the resolution in memory of the victims of totalitarian regimes because I believe in historical memory. Among other forbidden already in history, undemocratic regimes erased from history must be remembered the crimes of the Bolshevik one. Eastern Europe has been under a Bolshevi boot and terror for nearly half a century.  I give an example of the criminal insane idea of divided the Bulgarian nation and artificially created with the methods of terror macedonian one on Bulgarian territory. Therefore, these crimes must be condemned and their symbols, such as sickle, hammer and five-pointed, should also be prohibited as symbols of a totalitarian and undemocratic regime.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: . – Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution as one of the few born in this Chamber born into exile. We here, representing the people of Europe, have the hope of building a better Europe, but this is nothing new. Our parents and grandparents had the same hopes eighty years ago. However, two tyrants have wiped them all out, signing secret protocols and sharing Europe, causing the deadliest war in European history. Mass murders, holocaust, exiles. My parents and grandparents, along with tens of thousands of Lithuanian people, were also taken to Siberia in animal wagons. I was born there. Almost a decade after the war, we fought for freedom with a weapon in our hands. As you can see from the speeches here in this Chamber, some of you are not yet known about this period behind the Iron Curtain. Therefore, in order to be fair before our children and grandchildren and to build a fairer, happier Europe, we cannot allow similar tragedies to happen again.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Mr President, I voted against this resolution not because I don’t care about historical remembrance, but I care too much about historical facts and memory to allow them to be turned into a revisionist political football to push the EU’s contemporary agenda. This motion treats Europe and European history with disdain by flattening European history into the EU’s history. It hijacks the brave fight against fascism and the horrors of the Holocaust – by the way, you managed to forget the Jews in this motion – to push simplistic propaganda points about EU federalism and expansionism. European history is not EU history. The Renaissance, the Enlightenment, European arts and philosophy were the home and the clarion call of free speech, self—determination, nation states, national sovereignty and democracy. Those values this Parliament chooses to forget. I won’t. That’s why I oppose this motion, which was nothing more than political propaganda.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I think one of the most important clauses of the resolution we’ve approved today in the Parliament, and which I supported, is the importance of ensuring young people and future generations know and understand what happened during the darkest days of Europe’s past.  And in voting for this resolution, I pay particular tribute to the work of the National Holocaust Centre and Museum in the East Midlands, and the Holocaust Education Trust in the UK, who do vital work to ensure that young people and school students understand what happened and understand their role, and can be empowered to tackle hate and prejudice today. I also pay particular tribute to holocaust survivors who make it their personal mission today to ensure that those young people and all of us today understand the significance of what happened and can help empower all of us to ensure that when we say ‘never again’, we truly mean never again.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: - Mr President, Fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Europe must remember that the atrocities of the twentieth century against humanity will never be repeated, neither Nazism nor communism. The countries of Central and Eastern Europe are still grappling with the destructive effects of 50 years of communist and socialist dictatorship. In Romania, my generation was only partially affected, but the lives of my parents and grandparents were shattered by the Communist dictatorship. Reparations are little consolation, but they are also slow and incomplete. The return of real estate confiscated from historical churches and national minorities, despite being regulated by law, is not yet over. It is important to remind the Member States that real estate return laws are applied immediately and fully. In the eastern half of Europe, we have to make up for 50 years behind in development and mentality change. This is precisely what the European Union's Cohesion Funds are doing in catching up with Eastern Europe, but at the same time the idea of 'never happen again' must be continuously nurtured and passed on to the next generation. That is what we have done in this House today.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Mr President, I was pleased to support this motion to remember the victims of totalitarianism. For many of us this is very personal. My wife’s grandfather was an Auschwitz survivor and it chills me to the bone that things could easily have been very different, and my wife and my daughter would not exist. My own grandfathers were a paratrooper who fought in the war and a railwayman who had to keep trains at the docks moving while bombs fell from the sky.  We Europeans are united by history, by memory and resolve to make a better future. But I voted for the motion in spite of one reservation, which was that the motion speaks only of brutality by Europeans against other Europeans on the continent of Europe. The weight of our history is that Europeans have committed atrocities elsewhere too. There are Europeans today whose ancestors come from Asia, Africa and the Americas, and we must be clear that all atrocities are to be remembered. All our ancestors matter. Our Europe is part of the globe.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, 80 years ago, half a million Red Army troops backed by 5 000 tanks, 2 000 combat aircraft, smashed their way into Poland in a surprise attack. Masters of dezinformatsiya, they had first spread the story that they were coming to help their Slavic Brothers against the Nazis, but their intentions soon became clear. When the Nazi and Soviet armies met at Brest-Litovsk, they staged a joint parade. The two generals Guderian and Krivoshein had a slap-up lunch at which the Soviets invited the German journalists to join them in Moscow after the victory over capitalist Albion. The amnesia, the selective amnesia, that parts of the modern Left have about the Nazi—Soviet pact, is an extraordinary monument to the follies of human nature. We keep being told that the Red Army liberated us, that the Western theatre was just a sideshow, that it was really thanks to Stalin that fascism was defeated. Can we really have forgotten that for fully a third of the conflict they were on the same side? The only real victors here were the Left who ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I voted against the resolution as a whole even though I was in favour of certain paragraphs. I am against the whole approach of equating the Nazis to communist regimes. There is only one devil and the absolute devil is Nazi ideology. I am against the primitivisation of the approach to the history of World War II demonstrated by this resolution. Where is Munich? Forgotten. Where are the bilateral treaties concluded well before 23 August 1939? My family had to make sacrifices because of the Nazis; my family had to make sacrifices because of deportations. I repeat: there is only one devil and it is Nazi ideology.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, as a member of the Culture and Education Committee for the past five years, and now as a vice-chair of that same committee, I always seek to raise awareness of remembrance of our difficult history, whether that be through Erasmus+, the European Solidarity Corps or Creative Europe projects. I am here partly because my mother’s cousin, Kenny Chatfield, lies in a grave in northern France – shot down, aged 18, fighting fascism. The European Union is first and foremost a peace project, born out of the idea that Europe could not afford another world war. The material and human cost was immense, and we’ve moved from mass displacement and destruction across Europe to striving for peace and prosperity through common endeavour, cooperation and collaboration between European countries. These turning points in the past century should be told and understood across all Member States. Therefore I encourage those projects which themselves encourage tolerance, mutual understanding, intercultural dialogue and reconciliation.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I supported the resolution on the implementation of anti-money laundering legislation, because this issue is very important. We know cases such as the Panama Papers, as well as terrorist attacks in Europe, which were partly financed through money laundering, prove this. Sadly, ten European states have still not implemented the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive. I am glad that in this situation the Czech Republic is not among them. The Fifth Directive and its requirements in the form of stricter identity verification regimes and claims on banks are certainly appropriate. It is necessary for Member States to give more resources to their financial and analytical services, which should at the same time better exchange information. Unfortunately, even here, money laundering knows no borders, both explicitly and in a devolved sense. So international cooperation at EU level is globally necessary.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Mr President, this resolution is important. One percent of Europe's GDP is involved in suspicious financial activities. This is the equivalent of the annual budget of the European Union. Tax evaders and criminal or terrorist organizations depend on dubious bank relays, which is why the fight against money laundering must be carried out with the utmost firmness.  The Danske Bank scandal and all the others involved in a money laundering case of more than 200 billion euros revealed the weak capacity of the European Union to intervene. The European Banking Authority has shown its powerlessness by not taking any sanctions. The trans-partisan resolution I co-signed marks, I hope, an important first step in strengthening the anti-money laundering tools at European level. Of course, we will have to go further, and we cannot act effectively without establishing an exhaustive list of tax havens, because many of these notorious tax havens are within the European Union itself. Without attacking them, any policy will be doomed to failure.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Colleagues, I abstained as I understand and support the importance of combating money laundering, but at the same time I believe that some elements conflict with the competences of the Member States. Again, I see a proposal to create an agency to fight this and other problems again. But will another agency and the creation of bureaucratic procedures be the solution? In my opinion, no. And the answer must be a definite "no."  We need to be very careful and stick to the technical and legislative elements of the fight against money laundering without using them as tools to achieve political goals against individual countries, as we have in the case of Hungary and Poland.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on threats to the status of volunteer firefighters in the European Union (2019/2806(RSP)).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the title of this statement reflects the preoccupation that exists among the fire services in several Member States, notably in France, about the impact on volunteer firefighters of a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union last year in the Matzak case. I understand those worries and I hope I can assuage them at least to some extent. Of course, the Commission cannot speak for, or bind, the Court, but I can reassure you that we are following the situation of emergency services, including volunteer firefighters, very closely. Firefighters are a key element of emergency and civil protection services everywhere in Europe. Across the European Union, firefighting services are made up of a mixture of professional or career firefighters and volunteers. The composition of firefighting services varies greatly among different Member States. For instance, 80% of French firefighters are volunteers. The numbers are even higher in countries such as Germany or Austria, but in other countries, like Greece or Bulgaria, the firefighting workforce is almost entirely professionalised. To be clear, the Matzak judgment does not oblige Member States to have a particular mix of career firefighters and volunteer firefighters. It certainly does not oblige Member States to get rid of volunteer firefighters altogether or always to treat volunteers in exactly the same way as career professionals. The central issue of the Matzak judgment was about resting time and, more specifically, the entitlement to resting time for firefighters who, while on standby, are obliged, first, to live and stay permanently near to the fire station and, second, to respond to a call and reach the fire station within eight minutes. The Court concluded that, given these specific constraints, Mr Matzak’s standby time should be counted as working time for the purpose of the Working Time Directive and should not be seen as free time. Most of the ensuing debate about the Matzak case has been centered on the notion of ‘worker’. However, on that point the judgment said nothing new. A long line of case law makes clear that, under EU law, whether someone is considered a worker depends on the circumstances. Somebody who pursues real and genuine activities, who is subordinated to another person and who is remunerated in return, is a worker for the purposes of this piece of law. In the case of Mr Matzak, the Court concluded that, in his particular circumstances, these conditions were met. Following the judgment, various stakeholders jumped to the conclusion that EU law had made it impossible to have volunteer firefighters, but I believe this conclusion is incorrect. Let me be clear: there is no one—size—fits—all reply to the question of the status of volunteer firefighters under the Working Time Directive. Each specific case needs to be assessed against the criteria for qualification as a worker established by the Court, and, if the Working Time Directive does apply, its provisions on resting time should be respected. But the Working Time Directive offers a lot of flexibility for sectors such as firefighting and emergency services. For instance, derogations from daily and weekly rests are possible, of course, if compensatory rest is provided. Member States may also allow workers to opt out of the 48 hour average maximum working time under certain conditions, and in exceptional circumstances, such as natural or technological disasters, attacks or major incidents, the directive can be disapplied altogether. In summary, each case must be examined on its own merits to ensure that the status of volunteer is not used to circumvent European labour law. The Matzak judgment does not mean that every volunteer firefighter in the European Union automatically qualifies as a worker and, in any event, the Working Time Directive provides for flexibility to accommodate the needs of emergency services, such as fire services, without denying the firefighters protection of their health and safety.

name: Anne SANDER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, forest fires, floods, accidents, rescue, personal assistance... the list of services provided by volunteer firefighters is long and is growing year after year. The events of this summer have reminded us that their intervention is essential in our daily lives, to ensure the protection of citizens, businesses and rural areas. Volunteer firefighters are also helping to create social bonds, especially in rural areas. Their selfless civic commitment is essential for a more united Europe. In the European Union, among the 3 and a half million firefighters, there are many volunteers. In France, these volunteers make up 80% of the workforce. They alone account for two-thirds of the response time of protection services. Colleagues, I would like to sound the alarm here, because this model seems to us to be in danger. A ruling by the European Court of Justice in February 2018 described the situation of a Belgian volunteer firefighter in home care as working time. This volunteer firefighter's periods of duty were recognized as working time and were compensated. If this case is a case law, it will have to be clarified, but we are concerned that this breach will lead to the possible integration of volunteer firefighters into the scope of the Working Time Directive. The obligations set out in this directive in terms of rest time, work time, but also leave would therefore make the activity of volunteer firefighters incompatible with paid employment. There is therefore a real risk that volunteering will be confused with a workload. If that were the case, it would spell the end of our backup model. It would also undermine the free civic commitment of volunteerism. The consequences of this situation would be dramatic because of the legal uncertainty. Europe, of course, is supposed to promote forms of volunteerism and ensure the safety of its citizens. We end up with a situation where it would be quite the opposite. That is why we are mobilising, I am mobilising, with my colleagues here today, but also with all my colleagues in the EPP Group, and we are asking that the scope of this directive be clarified. We call on the European Commission to implement concrete actions, a framework to restore the legal security of the voluntary firefighter system.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Although this is the last debate in this plenary, it is one of the key. Especially for socialists and socialists and social democrats and social democrats. It concerns solidarity as our fundamental value and also the fundamental value of the European Union, as set out in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union, and, of course, the mission of voluntary assistance to others. Together, these two can really form a European way of life. In many countries of the European Union, voluntary firefighters are a pillar of protection against natural and other disasters. Volunteering in this area has a long tradition. In Slovenia we have been celebrating 150 years of volunteer firefighters this year and we are also the country within the European Union, which has the most voluntary firefighters in terms of population, 150 000 of all, 50 000 operational. In fact, voluntary firefighters in some Member States account for as much as 90% or even more of all firefighters.  And it is only the combination of voluntary and professional units that enables response and assistance in the event of fires, natural disasters, floods, cases of serious traffic accidents and other human distress. And in urban centers and in the countryside. At the same time, firefighters in Europe and beyond are ranked as the professional group of people most trusted by people. They are therefore a key part of civil protection because they ensure the personal safety of the population and contribute to public safety.  Of course, there are differences between national systems and ways of organising voluntary firefighting, and everywhere this is a noble mission. Individuals and individuals perform it in their spare time and without pay or compensation as an essential element of the employment relationship. Because they are not paid for their noble work or mission, they especially deserve our recognition, praise and thanks. Protection and protection against fires and other accidents is essentially the responsibility of the Member States. Through our decisions and legislative acts, meps of the European Parliament have an indirect or unintended influence on the status of volunteer firefighters in Europe. Not just positive. The 2003 Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain aspects of the organisation of working time was adopted with a view to protecting workers in the European Union. It sets minimum safety and health standards for the organisation of working time in all Member States, which is a major step forward in protecting workers' rights in the European Union.  The implementation of the Directive, especially following the Court's decision in the Matzak case of May 2018, according to which on-call time at home also for voluntary firefighters employed by private individuals is considered to be working time, means that female volunteers and volunteers could easily exceed the 48-hour working time, i.e. the maximum 48-hour working time per week, and the required 11 hours of daily rest. This is a high risk to the protection systems against natural and other disasters in the Member States, as volunteering could be prevented.  However, as a social democrat, I believe that the existing protection and definition of workers and the future protection and promotion of volunteering are equally important and are not mutually exclusive. We can't sacrifice one in the name of another. We need to improve the legal rules at most so that both are strengthened.  Namely, natural and other accidents do not know the working hours. They're unpredictable in scope and time. There will never be enough professional units, especially outside urban centres. That's why we have to do everything we can to keep volunteering.  It should be possible to coordinate the professional obligations and mission of a volunteer firefighter or fireman, to promote their recruitment and to ensure their equipment. The European Union Civil Protection Mechanism, the RescEU project, and in particular the Crisis Management Coordination Centre, are welcome to respond to major disasters, ensure effective solidarity between Member States and exchange good practices. With them we have obtained a reserve at European Union level that complements national systems and allows coordination or coordination and sharing of resources. However, it is essential to respect the principle of subsidiarity and to prevent centralisation. Over-regulation must be avoided, national traditions taken into account and without interfering with systems that work well and are trusted by people.  With optimism, I am thread that Commissioner-designate Janez Lenarčič knows very well the importance and role of voluntary firefighters. I believe that voluntary firefighters and firefighters under the direction of the department will be properly placed within the framework of EU mechanisms and that, in cooperation with the Member States and other Members of the Commission, there will be an improvement in their status.  However, I must point out that volunteering is not a form of work. Because of the dilemmas created by the 2003 Directive and the decision of the Court of Justice of the EU, we must not change the directive and the definition of worker or accept exceptions for individual countries or groups of countries. In particular, we must not at most to promote its reduction to a 35-hour weekly working day.  I therefore propose that we discuss a specific directive covering civil engagement for public security services. Within it, however, we make sure that status, safety and health standards are properly defined and the possibility of incentives or rewards for voluntary firefighters and firefighters are also given.  Voluntary firefighters contribute so much to our society that society is their society and we, as members of the European Union, owe it to them to give something back.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Basically, I can agree with the previous speakers: we really need to examine such a new, separate directive, and I would be glad if we could find planning certainty for our fire brigades here. In my Member State, Germany, there are currently 1.1 million active firefighters; 95% of these are members of the volunteer fire brigade. There are only about 100 professional fire brigades, but 24,000 volunteer fire brigades. I myself come from a very rural region in the Oberallgäu; the nearest professional fire brigade is located 150 kilometres away in Augsburg. Volunteering is not limited to the fire brigades. Across Germany, there are 1.8 million volunteers in civil protection, fire brigades and emergency services. In my state, Bavaria, there are 470 000 rescue workers; of these, 450 000 are voluntary and voluntary. These figures clearly show that volunteering is the backbone of our fire and rescue system. But not only that. Especially in rural areas, the volunteer fire brigade plays a central role in social life. The exchange of all age groups among themselves in all social classes is specifically maintained here. We must therefore promote and protect this commitment. Volunteering should be fulfilled and must not frustrate. Now we have this European Working Time Directive – my predecessors referred to this – and we must, of course, state that voluntary working time cannot be offset against working time from the working occupations. That would be a threat to our entire rescue system. In Germany, we have assumed for many years that voluntary services do not fall within this scope. And now we have this court ruling, which again worries us, because we must not define the volunteer fire brigade as workers in the sense of a normal professional life. We need legal certainty and we need clarity for our volunteer fire brigade. Unfortunately, we are not making any progress at all here at the moment, and all the only thing that remains for us and all the volunteers is that we will actually find solutions here at European level. Our voluntary service system has proved its worth and plays an important role in the growing social fabric. We must therefore finally find tangible solutions so that voluntary work remains possible at European level without any ifs and buts.

name: Guido REIL
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of this Parliament, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I greet you and I greet the representatives of the voluntary fire brigade who are present very warmly. It is nice that you have found the long way to Strasbourg to fight for your honorary office. What are we talking about today? We are talking about the future of voluntary fire brigades in Europe, and that is what we are talking about the safety of Europe. I am new here, and I expected a number of things to be decided and discussed here, which does not always help the people of Europe, but harm them. But I honestly couldn't imagine it being so crass in my worst nightmares. I also just wonder what the representatives of the voluntary fire brigade think when they see that this important issue is being discussed here shortly after three with fourteen Members. So they didn't deserve more? Did they not deserve more attention, not more support? So what are we talking about? In Germany, 1.1 million people are involved in the fire brigade, 95% volunteer – five-and-nine-tens of percent! These people are needed. They do an incredibly important job. It is not just about security, it is also about social life. They are the core of social and cultural life in the entire rural area. This commitment needs support and deserves our support. We are constantly talking about promoting volunteering, and now we are doing exactly the opposite. When we talk about the crediting of working hours to voluntary work, where do we start and where do we stop? What about the Rifle King, who sits on the throne during the festival – does he spend his working time there? What about the representatives of the carnival clubs? What about coaches who coach youth teams? Do they spend their working time there? These are issues that need to be clarified in principle and which make me angry that we are even talking about such nonsense. We are talking about completely unworldly issues that no one out there cares about. We are creating problems here, we are creating problems ourselves, and that is the core of the EU. I call here quite clearly: fingers away from the voluntary fire brigade, fingers away from volunteering, immediately! Good luck!

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is a Polish saying: "Longer monastery like a thud". The first mention of the volunteer fire brigade, about how citizens, people were able to shout to help each other when it comes to Poland, goes back to the Middle Ages.  Today's TSO, or Volunteer Fire Brigade, has had more than a hundred years in this modern history of our country and Europe. This discussion, which takes place here, shows that sometimes – as another Polish saying says – we try to pour a child with a bath. Let us leave alone those who have been able to cope with their time for centuries, including those who voluntarily sacrifice to save their health, their lives, their own achievements or their neighbours. I will use numbers. There are more than 16,000 Volunteer Fire Brigades in Poland, of which more than 4,300 units today operate under the National Fire and Rescue System, i.e. they support this professional, state guard. That's more than 225,000 firefighters who can take part in direct rescue efforts. In total, the Volunteer Fire Brigades bring together almost 700 000 people in Poland, including – worth highlighting – 82 000 are children and young people, because, as has been mentioned here, also on the example of other countries, these voluntary fire brigades are often in their small homelands, in their municipalities, in the villages where they operate, especially in rural areas, are such a cultural centre and forming social ties.  The government, which I had the privilege of representing as minister of the interior, also responsible for the fire brigade, the Government of Law and Justice in Poland for the first time took over the Volunteer Fire Brigades program of modernization of uniformed services. For the first time, we have harmonised the legislation in such a way that the Volunteer Fire Brigades can be supported. In conclusion, I would like to say to the Old Polish custom of the bridesmaids and bridesmaids of the Volunteer Fire Brigades: God's happiness! And may your patron Saint Florian always have you in his care.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, today in this Chamber, I am delighted because we are trying to make invisibles visible. Our eyes are used to firefighters, we don't see them anymore! I am talking about men and women whom each of us have probably already crossed in each of our Member States, stopped at the side of the road or blackened by fire fumes. It is thanks to their strength of vocation and dedication that all this is possible. Who are we talking about, then? As I said, men and women everywhere respond to distress calls, in big cities, small villages, in all weathers, rain, snow, wind. At every moment, when you, your loved ones or your friends, all citizens, need help, they will be there, benevolent; they'll be there, perhaps, to save your life. So these men and women are the firefighters. Just yesterday, ladies and gentlemen, if you took public transport like me to come to Parliament, you could not escape this one that cries out for their distress. Colleagues, today, these firefighters, our firefighters see red and this is, I think, the time to thank them in this Chamber and to pay tribute to them. I would add that in France there is a strike by firefighters, and I give them my unwavering support. In France, as in most of our Member States, the vast majority (80%) interventions are carried out by voluntary teams. Of course, volunteers receive compensation, that's the least we can do! But when are we going to really give them the recognition they deserve? During their service, they do not benefit from any pension contributions, any contributions for the risks they incur, or any protective status. We cannot accept that these men and women are cut and hard at will, and I assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that their safety is our responsibility. The day before yesterday, I was talking to a firefighter from the Pyrenees-Atlantic. He told me the story of a 21-year-old volunteer firefighter who was burned in the hands, arms and thighs while trying to save his colleagues from a deadly fire. Today, this young volunteer firefighter has to pay back 9,000 euros. What for? Because the medical expert considered that it was not in the context of his work! I ask you the question: if it was you he saved, you who, today, are sitting comfortably in your chair... put yourself in his place! Double punishment assured, you would be touched both in your flesh and in your wallet, simply for doing your duty.  So let's go back to volunteer status. Indeed, this status has just been challenged by a judgment of the European Court of Justice, which recognises the qualification of workers, in accordance with the directive on the limitation of working time. We can only appreciate the trajectory it indicates. However, this change in status implies a profound change in the organization of firefighters. And many, I see them, are already calling for an exception to the directive. So, to these, to these great profit-head explorers, I say that they are very wrong. Volunteer status is not the answer. We have to go back to service and the common good. Finally, I will say that those who protect us today need us to protect them, so that their motto, which is 'save or perish', never becomes 'save and perish'.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the Commission for this communication, which was highly anticipated, as far as I am concerned, on this sensitive subject, in view of the issues that are currently the case for those involved in the emergency model. In this speech today, which is my first speech , since I am a brand new Member of Parliament - in plenary session, as an MEP, let me stress three points. My first point reminds me that there are about 3.5 million volunteer firefighters in the European Union and I would like to acknowledge their commitment to the service of all, as my colleagues have done, at a time when climate change is, alas, leading to more and more natural disasters. This is how the excitement caused by the Matzac decision must be properly measured. This court ruling, considering the volunteer time of certain categories of firefighters carrying out home guarding as working time, may have surprised while concerning a very specific situation, which is not that of all volunteer firefighters. In this context, it is clear that this first clarification is more than welcome - thank you for that, Commissioner. I'm coming to my second point. I have listened carefully, Commissioner. I have noted that, in the Commission's view, the specificities of national models must be taken into account. I have also heard that you have rightly pointed out the importance of the principle of subsidiarity in this area. I am very happy about that. This approach should preserve the material organisation of our emergency services and keep intact the possibility of mobilising men and women in emergency situations throughout the European Union. It is, of course, this preservation that I call for. Finally, my third point is more general. Today's debate is an opportunity to recall the urgent need to support civil protection mechanisms through the appropriate European instruments. We need to encourage more coordination of our relief systems. We need to consolidate the European Civil Security Mechanism, pool our resources and disaster scenarios, and share our expertise. In conclusion, I would like to express my relief at this plenary meeting today. Let us preserve these national models of civil security, some of which are based in particular on altruism and volunteerism, which work well and ensure the territorial proximity of relief efforts. At the same time, let us boost the European Union's action by leveraging and at the level where it is effective.  It is for this Europe that I am committed, the one that always better protects its citizens, the one that supports the different forms of engagement in society, the one that allows them to express concretely what solidarity and self-giving is for the community.

name: André ROUGÉ
text: Madam President, dear but too few colleagues, courage and dedication, motto of the volunteer firefighters, these two words are there to remind us, if need be, that every day, volunteer and professional firefighters are ready to sacrifice their lives to save our own. Every day, French people, farmers, craftsmen, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs and SMEs, take the uniform to help us.  However, the courage and dedication of this generous commitment to the community is poorly rewarded. Every day our firefighters are assaulted in response. Our volunteer firefighters feel very alone and poorly regarded. Their situation does not seem to have improved since Marine Le Pen's last intervention on the subject last year.  The jurisprudence of the European Court of Justice will make it impossible to reconcile their services and professional activity. For accounting, budgetary and above all civic reasons, full professionalization should not be conceivable. Daily and crisis relief will no longer be assured as it is today, to the detriment of the French and the resilience of our society.  The French model of civil security is based on volunteerism, which accounts for 80 per cent of the fire brigade workforce in France. Since professionalisation is neither desirable nor possible, it is therefore essential to adopt a specific directive during this new European mandate. Beyond the legal debate, the issue is political and civic, it concerns other European countries. This is a choice of values and society. A volunteer firefighter is now committed to protecting his fellow citizens and his territory.  In the context of the acceleration and increasing of civil security crises, it is more necessary than ever to be able to count on the civic commitment of volunteer firefighters throughout Europe. That is why at the ID group and the National Rally chaired by Marine Le Pen, we adhere to the proposals of the National Federation of Firefighters of France.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I would like to thank the Commissioner, firstly, for his respect for the volunteer fire brigades and for highlighting the diversity of the way volunteer fire brigades operate in the European Union. I think that overregulation can only be involved in volunteering and associations – because that is how the volunteer fire brigade operates in Poland – simply to harm. We should move our discussions within our countries.  I have the honour to represent Poland and I can say that over the last three years there has been a significant increase in expenditure. These are the decisions and actions of support, and the emphasis on this respect for the volunteer fire brigades. This is money and an increase of 30%...  (The President received the speaker's vote because her statement was not in accordance with the blue card procedure)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, over the past few years we have witnessed many security incidents endangering the lives of the citizens of our countries. Especially in recent months and weeks we have witnessed large-scale fires that incinerate property, property and endanger the lives of citizens. Volunteers are often joined to help regular firefighters. I am a volunteer myself and have been involved in the extinguishing of forest fires and know first-person how difficult this task is and how difficult this job is. We must not allow regulation in legislation at European level to jeopardise the status, life and health of volunteer firefighters in the Member States. In 2018, the Court of Justice of the European Union in its case determined that the time a Belgian citizen spends as a volunteer firefighter should be counted as working time. This sets a precedent in some member states where volunteering is regulated at national level and would in practice mean that volunteer firefighters would have two jobs each. I think it's clear to everyone what problems all this can lead to.  Directive 2003/88 on aspects of the organisation of working time is negotiated and drawn up in a different context from today, and its aim should in no case be to intimidate or discourage volunteers, but to protect the rights of vulnerable employees. With all due respect to the work of the European Court of Justice, I believe that we should not be left to be guided by interpretations of the Court of Justice, especially in this case, which, instead of bringing legal clarity, creates legal chaos in many Member States, in areas related to the protection of citizens' health and life and the environment. I believe that we need to work towards a solution on this issue so as to avoid the threat posed to the status and motivation of volunteer firefighters.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Indeed, there are not many of us here in this House today, but we come from different political groups and from different countries, and we all actually say the same thing. Indeed, volunteer fire brigade units are an important part of the safety system in all Member States. This service is an example of courage and dedication carried selflessly and often at the risk of life. But this is also a great example of building social capital, and that's what we're all about.  In many villages in my region, in my constituency, the history of such units dates back to the beginning of the 19th century, for example in Nakle, in Rynarzewa or in Kcyni, where the guard is already more than two hundred years old. Dear! If there is such agreement here in this House, I would like to emphasise, Commissioner, that I agree with socialist MEMBER Mr Brglez, who said that we receive a lot from firefighters and we have to give them a lot.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I have listened attentively to your interventions and I hope I was able to allay some of the worries that have been expressed concerning the status of volunteer firefighters in the European Union.  Volunteer firefighters are a pillar of emergency and civil protection services in many Member States and their contribution to the efficiency of those services is undisputed. I can add that I have a great personal respect for their commitment. The organisation and the functioning of firefighting services is and remains a competence of individual Member States and each Member State has its own specificities and needs. But it is important to protect the health and safety of volunteers and to ensure that the status of volunteer is not used to circumvent labour law where such law is applicable.  As I explained in my introduction, the existing rules offer the flexibility to organise this. Now, from my side, I am happy to facilitate contacts between different Member States that might be affected by the Matzak ruling of the Court of Justice so that there is a platform to discuss solutions that were found in many Member States. A specific directive for civil protection has been proposed by the French Senate and by the Fédération nationale des sapeurs-pompiers. I doubt whether this is really necessary, or whether this is the best solution, but you understand that as a member of the outgoing Commission, I cannot commit the next Commission to initiate such a proposal. But I’m happy that I could give you some elements – the key elements, I think – to take a well-informed position in the discussion that you will for sure continue with my successor.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: Writing. – The role and importance of volunteer firefighters and other volunteers in the system of protection against natural and other disasters is increasing due to the worsening consequences of natural and other disasters.  I call on the Commission to undertake to prepare a European legal framework that will properly and fairly remedy their situation. The fact is that climate change is making the consequences of natural disasters more serious and extensive, and the work of volunteer firefighters and other volunteers in crisis response systems is becoming more demanding and accountable. This must therefore also be followed by the regulation of their situation, in particular the regulation of their economic and social and legal situation.  The issue of industrial relations, of course, is at the forefront, where we need to find an appropriate systemic solution to the relationship between a volunteer firefighter and his employer. Of course, this is not the only dilemma, it is also a question of legal liability, insurance for salic-related risks, etc.  I therefore call once again on the Commission to address this issue as a matter of priority.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Firefighters are a professional group that has consistently enjoyed great, if not the greatest, public trust for years. This is m.in. because we can count on firefighters not only for fires, natural disasters, disasters, but also for many other hazards.  A few months ago, it was here in Strasbourg that the Law and Justice delegation organised an exhibition that illustrated true European solidarity – the heroic Polish firefighters who last year helped in the firefighting operation in Sweden.  In my homeland, Poland, volunteer fire brigades play a huge role, especially in the daily lives of small, local communities. It is around them that not only rescue operations, but also educational and cultural and sporting events are often concentrated. This role was recognised by the Government of the Republic of Poland, which included voluntary fire brigades with statutory support, which will allow not only the promotion of first aid rules, but also fire protection and prevention. Significant resources for equipment and training for volunteer firefighters are also regularly donated. We are aware that they have often saved people's health and lives, and these values have no price. Therefore, their attitude deserves the utmost respect and support.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Members of voluntary firefighting associations, voluntary rescue services and civil protection play a very important role throughout Europe and thus in Hungary. They voluntarily protect people's lives, health, material values, basic care of the population, the natural environment, natural values in their free time. Their work, which requires serious expertise and is often dangerous, requires great determination and their performance is honourable. National specificities and customs vary in the rules applicable to them in EU countries, such as the regulation of their working time. However, it is important that, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, this remains the case and that Member States can decide for themselves what the conditions for voluntary work are and the number of hours in which this important activity can be carried out and the length of rest periods they are entitled to.  I take this opportunity to point out here that users of the Nationally and Free Emergency Information System (EMERGENCY) for smartphones and tablets in Hungary can obtain fresh knowledge about the current situation, fires, accidents, power outages or alerts issued by meteorology about the current situation in their place of residence, the areas affected by their destination, monitored routes, counties or even the whole country. The app can be used to prevent accidents and improve user safety.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Voluntary fire brigades are undoubtedly a very important element in the rescue system of most EU Member States. Their members are well-trained women and men, who are usually the first to provide sacrificial assistance to victims at the scene. They also work closely with other services to ensure the safety of citizens in the area of their activities (cities, municipalities) or neighbouring areas.  There are more than 1,800 TSOs with nearly 96,000 volunteers in the Wielkopolska region of Poland, whose inhabitants have entrusted me with the mandate of an MEP. Most of them are men, but women's teams are also very numerous, as they have more than 2.5 thousand members. It is worth noting that in Wielkopolska there are also more than 1,000 youth fire teams with 13,4 000 members, including nearly 5,000 girls.  I believe that the hard work of the volunteer fire brigades deserves the highest recognition. I am all the more concerned about the risks that may arise to the status of voluntary fire services in the European Union. I firmly believe that we should take every action to ensure that the status of volunteer firefighter in the EU remains intact. Moreover, the European Commission and Parliament should bear in mind that the effectiveness of voluntary guards depends to a large extent on whether they have specialised fire-fighting equipment and whether they are properly funded.
